A barbershop quartet dressed up in medieval fantasy garb walks into the cafe and up to a neighbouring table, at which a young man and woman are sitting.
As the quartet sings a Boyz II Men song, the man drops down on one knee and pulls out a ring. The woman starts to break out in happy tears.

Two young, long-haired men walk into the coffee shop and order Italian sodas. As they leave, they wave at Artemis, who waves back in recognition.

background.speaker: artemis
background.line: (Wave at the audience.)

background.line: Ask if those are friends of #artemisPos#

Magical café music
♩♩♫♫
A pair of nondescript teenage girls walk into the cafe and make a beeline straight for the bathroom.
Literally thirty seconds later, they come out of the bathroom dressed as magical girls from some anime show, complete with sparkly, unintentionally suggestively-shaped weapons at their disposal.
They run off, presumably to fight crime or something.

background.speaker: artemis
background.line: Express amazement at how those girls changed into their costumes so fast

Regency-era pianoforte music
♩♩♫♫
At a neighbouring table, a couple of people dressed as Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy from Pride and Prejudice appear to be having some kind of heated argument.
Elizabeth, fed up with this nonsense, stands up and yells, 'yeah, well, it is a truth universally acknowledged that you suck!'
Then, she storms out the cafe in a huff, leaving Mr. Darcy fuming.

background.line: Express sympathy for poor Mr. Darcy

At a neighbouring table, two young people sit side by side, staring into each other's eyes and looking like they're almost about to snog each other's faces off.

Just The Way You Look Tonight
A saxophone-laden instrumental arrangement of an old jazz standard plays ambiently in the background.

Raiders March (Indiana Jones theme) played on bagpipes
Outside, a handful of bagpipers walk by, playing the Raiders March theme in unison as a row of snare drummers plays a precise beat behind them.
Robots can't count the beat, what what whatever
At a neighbouring table, a middle-aged man excitedly tells his friend about a new robot girlfriend he custom ordered from Japan.

He complains that the shipping is taking forever, but consoles himself with the knowledge that the company he ordered from makes the most ultra-realistic robots available to consumers at this point in time.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
Behind the counter, one of the baristas eagerly shows the manager an article on Japanese cat cafes. The manager, likely thinking about licencing fees and veterinary bills, is nonplussed.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
An elderly couple walks into the coffee shop, kvetching all the while about all the young hooligans who appear to be encroaching upon the neighbourhood this weekend.
They make small talk with the barista, who serves them their usual matching orders of black coffee. The couple then walks out, still complaining all the while.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
A middle-aged woman with a side shave and a floral print skirt wanders inside the coffee shop, appearing to look for someone.
After glancing around for a minute, she leaves, appearing not to have found whomever it was she was looking for.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫

At a neighbouring table, an eight-year-old girl attempts to solve a Sudoku from one of the complimentary newspapers while her mom texts on her smartphone so furiously, it's like her fingers are going to fall off.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
At a neighbouring table, a heavily-tattooed man musters up the courage to convince his girlfriend to give open relationships a try. He appears to be surprised at how eager she is about the idea.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
At a neighbouring table, a cuddly-looking, dark-haired, bowtie-wearing person of mysterious and indistinct gender sits hunched over, furiously typing on a laptop covered in stickers.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
At a neighbouring table, one slick-looking man in a well-tailored business suit gives a pitch on dream-based marketing to another almost-identical slick-looking man in a well-tailored business suit.

The second man is somewhat concerned about the privacy invasiveness of the technology, but the first man reassures him that they won't be using any information that isn't already available publicly over the internet.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
At a neighbouring table, two white men in black t-shirts and jeans jabber excitedly about a new level design tool for first person videogames in which you point a gun and shoot to create scenery.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
Behind the counter, a couple of baristas gossip about banal relationship drama of some sort or another.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
A clatter sounds from somewhere behind the counter. One of the baristas curses loudly and sets about mopping up the mess.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
Outside, a unicyclist in a bear costume passes by, swerving dangerously to avoid a group of loitering teenage boys taking up an entire section of sidewalk.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
At the counter, a confused patron loudly complains about having to solve a skill-testing puzzle in order to get the wifi password.
The barista calmly offers to help the customer reason through the puzzle, which only makes said customer even more irate.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
Outside, a tall, lipstick red-haired woman walks by who appears to be wearing tights made of spiders and seven inch stiletto heels..
She almost trips over a manhole cover, but deftly sidesteps and regains her balance, continuing to sassily make her way to her destination.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
Outside, a bunch of young, twentysomething men wearing horse hooves and tails gallop across the street with very, very serious looks on their faces.
They almost knock over a middle-aged, bespectacled woman, who yells at them to watch where they're going.

Boring café music
♩♩♫♫
A group of about a dozen ninjas walks into the coffee shop very, very quietly.

No one notices that they've arrived until they've already left, however, with the only trace of their existence being some missing danishes from the pastry counter and some very, very confused looks on the baristas' faces.

zeffIntro.line: It's mid-afternoon at Cuthbert's Coffee, a relatively quiet cafe outside the hustle and bustle of the Terminal City Convention Centre, where AwesomeCon 2014 is being held.

zeffIntro.speaker: artemis
zeffIntro.line: (Sip your coffee while staring at your smartphone.)

zeffIntro-nervous.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-nervous.line: (Walk up to Artemis, fidgeting nervously. Don't sit down just yet.)

zeffIntro-confident.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-confident.line: (Walk up to Artemis, feigning confidence to mask the nervousness you feel. Don't sit down just yet.)

zeffIntro-hello.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-hello.line: Uh, excuse me... are you Artemis Fiddler of Bacteria Stories?

zeffIntro-hello.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-hello.line: Mention you're a fan of #artemisDet# work

zeffIntro-twitter.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-twitter.line: I hope this isn't too awkward, but, uh, I follow you on Twitter. I'm @ZeffOMatic on there.

zeffIntro-twitter.speaker: artemis
zeffIntro-twitter.line: Oh! Right! Uh... yeah. It's hard to keep track of who's on Twitter. I mean, there are so many people on it and all...

zeffIntro-twitter.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-twitter.line: I understand. I mean, someone as popular as you probably has a lot of followers, huh?

zeffIntro-twitter.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-twitter.line: Ask if you can sit with #artemisObj#

zeffIntro-fan.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-fan.line: I'm a huge fan of your webcomic. It's been on my news feed since 2011.

zeffIntro-fan.speaker: artemis
zeffIntro-fan.line: Apologise for the lull in updates

zeffIntro-lull.speaker: artemis
zeffIntro-lull.line: In that case, I apologise in advance for not updating it as often since then. As you can imagine, life got in the way.

zeffIntro-lull.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-lull.line: Ask if you can sit with #artemisObj#

zeffIntro-flattered.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-flattered.line: Ask if you can sit with #artemisObj#

zeffIntro-okayToSit.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-okayToSit.line: So... is it okay if I sit here?

zeffIntro-sitDown.speaker: zeff
zeffIntro-sitDown.line: (Sit down at the table across from Artemis.)

awesomeCon.speaker: zeff
awesomeCon.line: So, uh, you having a good AwesomeCon?

awesomeCon.speaker: artemis
awesomeCon.line: Say it's better than you thought it'd be

awesomeCon-worse.speaker: artemis
awesomeCon-worse.line: Eh, I dunno. It's a con, I guess. Could be worse.

awesomeCon-worse.speaker: zeff
awesomeCon-worse.line: Say it surely must be at least a little awesome

awesomeCon-howSo.speaker: artemis
awesomeCon-howSo.line: Well, for starters, I finally found a coffee shop around here that isn't overrun by hordes of ninja zombie cosplayers accompanied by really bad dubstep music. So, that's something.

awesomeCon-howSo.speaker: zeff
awesomeCon-howSo.line: Heh, yeah, it sure does get loud on that expo floor, doesn't it? Hard to hear yourself think.

awesomeCon-surelyItMust.speaker: zeff
awesomeCon-surelyItMust.line: Aw, come on. It's AwesomeCon! Surely it has to be at least a little bit awesome, right?

awesomeCon-better.speaker: artemis
awesomeCon-better.line: Better than I thought it'd be, actually. Of course, I don't think I was expecting all that much.

weather.speaker: zeff
weather.line: Nice weather we're having today, isn't it?

weather.speaker: artemis
weather.line: Hmm, I prefer when it's overcast, especially on days when I'm spending most of my time indoors.

weather.speaker: zeff
weather.line: Talk about how you've been out enjoying the sun

weather.speaker: zeff
weather.line: Say you're prone to SAD in the winter months

weather-enjoying.speaker: zeff
weather-enjoying.line: I was actually out enjoying the sun for a bit. It seems like a waste of a perfectly good day to hole myself inside the convention centre.

weather-sad.speaker: zeff
weather-sad.line: Well, I get seasonal affective disorder in the winter, so actually being in a place where there's sunlight feels really refreshing to me.

coffeeShops.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops.line: I like this coffee shop. It's got a charmingly old-fashioned ambiance.

coffeeShops.speaker: artemis
coffeeShops.line: Yeah. And it's relatively empty, too. I figure everyone at AwesomeCon usually winds up at the Expresso next door, instead.

coffeeShops.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops.line: Right. An Expresso. That explains it.

coffeeShops.speaker: artemis
coffeeShops.line: I can't stand Expresso. I'll only go there if I'm desperate. Like I'm in a small town and the only options are Expresso and that brown powdery stuff that comes in a can.

coffeeShops.speaker: artemis
coffeeShops.line: Plus, they're singlehandedly responsible for perpetuating the mispronunciation of the word espresso, which is doubly annoying.

coffeeShops.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops.line: Say Expresso isn't all that bad

coffeeShops.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops.line: Say you don't even like espresso

coffeeShops-notThatBad.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops-notThatBad.line: Hey, Expresso isn't all that bad. I happen to like their pumpkin spiced chai lattes.

coffeeShops-notThatBad.speaker: artemis
coffeeShops-notThatBad.line: Mention that Cuthbert's actually knows how to make a good dark roast

coffeeShops-dontLikeEspresso.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops-dontLikeEspresso.line: I don't even like espresso drinks. I'd rather have tea instead.

coffeeShops-dontLikeEspresso.speaker: artemis
coffeeShops-dontLikeEspresso.line: Mention that Cuthbert's actually knows how to make a good dark roast

coffeeShops-darkRoast.speaker: artemis
coffeeShops-darkRoast.line: You know what I really like about this coffee shop? They actually know how to make a good dark roast. I can't tell you how sick and tired I am of the hipster trend towards acidic, sour coffee.

coffeeShops-darkRoast.speaker: artemis
coffeeShops-darkRoast.line: Coffee is supposed to look and smell like rich garden soil on a rainy day. I don't care that so-called coffee snobs feel the need to claim otherwise.

coffeeShops-darkRoast.description: Went off on a rant about coffee

coffeeShops-darkRoast.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops-darkRoast.line: Say you never really developed a taste for coffee, period

coffeeShops-darkRoast.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops-darkRoast.line: Say it sounds like #artemisSub# know how to make up #artemisDet# mind.

coffeeShops-taste.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops-taste.line: I find that all coffee either tastes too sour or too bitter. I guess I never really developed a taste for it. Probably a good thing too; the last thing I need at this point in my life is a caffeine addiction.

coffeeShops-taste.speaker: artemis
coffeeShops-taste.line: Heh. Guilty as charged. The last time I tried to go off coffee, I was irritable and headachey and hated everyone and everything.

coffeeShops-taste.speaker: artemis
coffeeShops-taste.line: Then again, I also had a really bad cold at the time, which probably made it even worse.

coffeeShops-knowsWhatTheyLike.speaker: zeff
coffeeShops-knowsWhatTheyLike.line: Well, it sounds like you know what you like, and I think that makes you enough of a coffee snob for anyone. I mean that in the best possible way, of course.

artemisBooth.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth.line: I tried to head over to your table, but it was super packed. Have you been selling a lot of artwork?

artemisBooth.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth.line: Not a super huge amount, actually. Most of the traffic's been for the other artists at the table.

artemisBooth.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth.line: I guess it doesn't really help that I haven't made my comic into a book yet; that seems to be the thing that gets the most people buying stuff. And I don't have any t-shirts or other merch, either.

artemisBooth.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth.line: Say that you would totally buy #artemisDet# books and t-shirts

artemisBooth.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth.line: Tell #artemisObj# about your Bacteria Kittens t-shirt idea

artemisBooth-totally.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth-totally.line: Well, if you put out a book, I would totally buy it and ask for you to sign it. And I'd get a shirt, too. Just saying.

artemisBooth-totally.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-totally.line: Say it's a lot of work to put out

artemisBooth-thanks.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-thanks.line: Mention that you feel kind of underprepared

artemisBooth-work.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-work.line: Eh, it's a lot of work to get that stuff made, at least if you don't decide to get it done by an el cheapo print on demand service. What with my day job and all, I don't have a lot of time to write the comic, period, let alone worry about merch.

artemisBooth-work.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-work.line: Mention that you feel kind of underprepared

artemisBooth-kittens.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth-kittens.line: You know, I've always thought it'd be a great idea if you made t-shirts of the Bacteria Kittens. I'd definitely wear one.

artemisBooth-kittens.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-kittens.line: I'm actually not entirely sure how that particular strip got so popular. It was a one-off thing I drew one day when I was out of ideas.

artemisBooth-kittens.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth-kittens.line: Well, you know. Kittens are always a sure thing for success where internet memes are concerned.

artemisBooth-kittens.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-kittens.line: Mention that you feel kind of underprepared

artemisBooth-underprepared.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-underprepared.line: Anyway, I'm pretty new to all this con stuff. The only reason I got a table in the first place was because Dan Carbonetto had an extra space he wanted to fill. So, as you can imagine, I've been kind of underprepared.

artemisBooth-underprepared.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth-underprepared.line: Mention you're unfamiliar with who Dan Carbonetto is

artemisBooth-carbonetto.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth-carbonetto.line: Dan Carbonetto? I don't think I know who he is.

artemisBooth-carbonetto.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-carbonetto.line: Oh, he does the comic Booger & Snotface. We're... acquaintances, I guess? We talked a few of times at this meetup we both frequent, but I'm not really in his immediate circle of artist friends.

artemisBooth-carbonetto.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth-carbonetto.line: Ah, Booger & Snotface. Yeah, I've seen that comic before. It's not consistently good enough to make it into my regular reading, but the strips I get linked to on occasion are pretty funny.

artemisBooth-carbonetto.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-carbonetto.line: Sounds about right. He's mostly harmless and doesn't really offend anyone, which gives him so much popular appeal, but I wouldn't say he's truly great, either.

artemisBooth-carbonetto.speaker: artemis
artemisBooth-carbonetto.line: Of course, he actually makes a living off of the comic, so what do I know about anything?

artemisBooth-short.speaker: zeff
artemisBooth-short.line: Hey, don't sell yourself short. I think it's awesome that you're here, regardless of preparedness. And I hope you keep coming back.

zeffAwesomeCon.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon.line: How about you? Have you seen anything at AwesomeCon that you feel is particularly awesome?

zeffAwesomeCon.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon.line: Talk about the virtual reality hamster ball game on the expo floor

zeffAwesomeCon.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon.line: Talk about the panel about women in the videogame industry

zeffAwesomeCon.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon.line: Talk about bumping into that famous internet videoblog celebrity, Parcheesi

zeffAwesomeCon.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon.line: Talk about the game controller shaped like a hand

zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.line: Well, on the expo floor, I saw this giant hamster ball-like treadmill thing attached to a virtual reality headset.

zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.line: It was for some game where you get to play as a hamster running around and knocking into people's feet and furniture and stuff. It looked really cool.

zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.line: I take it you enjoyed running around and pretending to be a hamster, then?

zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.line: Oh, I didn't actually get to play. The line was way too long. They actually had to put signs up, like they do in Disneyland and such, that tell you it's two and a half hours until your turn. I didn't want to wait that long.

zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.line: Say that's exactly why you can't stand Disneyland

zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-hamster.line: Suggest that someone should make a game about waiting in line for the hamster ball game

zeffAwesomeCon-disneyland.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-disneyland.line: And that's why I can't stand Disneyland. Or expo floors at conventions, for that matter.

zeffAwesomeCon-disneyland.description: Pissed off the Walt Disney Company

zeffAwesomeCon-line.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-line.line: Maybe someone should make a game about waiting in line for the hamster ball game. And then the people in line can play that game while they wait in line. Or something.

zeffAwesomeCon-women.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-women.line: I went on a panel on women in the videogame industry.

zeffAwesomeCon-women.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-women.line: Women in the videogame industry, huh? That sounds like it could be interesting.

zeffAwesomeCon-women.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-women.line: It was! There was this one panelist who kept being all contrarian; she said something along the lines that she was hoping that by this time next year, sexism would be over and she wouldn't have to speak at women in games panels anymore.

zeffAwesomeCon-women.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-women.line: I got the feeling that the other panelists were overly cautious not to say anything that could be construed as negative to their employers, though.

zeffAwesomeCon-women.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-women.line: Huh. I normally don't like going to panels because they're always filled with people agreeing with one another, but I do like it when someone tries to shake things up.

zeffAwesomeCon-women.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-women.line: I also hate it when people go up to ask questions that aren't really questions but more like their entire life story.

zeffAwesomeCon-women.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-women.line: Talk about how the contrarian panelist actually called out that behaviour

zeffAwesomeCon-women.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-women.line: Try not to let on that you've totally asked those kinds of non-questions before

zeffAwesomeCon-callOut.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-callOut.line: That's funny. The contrarian panelist actually said something like, um, that's not a question, to one of the audience members.

zeffAwesomeCon-callOut.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-callOut.line: Heh. Sounds like someone I wouldn't mind knowing.

zeffAwesomeCon-ummYeah.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-ummYeah.line: Yeah... uh... that can be pretty annoying, huh?

zeffAwesomeCon-flash.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-flash.line: There was a flash mob out in front of the main hall! There were like a hundred people dressed like space marines who all came out and did a super choreographed routine to that Everybody Dance Now song.

zeffAwesomeCon-flash.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-flash.line: Wow. I never got the impression that con-goers were of the dancing sort.

zeffAwesomeCon-flash.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-flash.line: Oh, they aren't. A lot of people were really, really confused. Especially those teenage boys who actually like stuff with space marines in it.

zeffAwesomeCon-flash.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-flash.line: I talked to one of the dancers afterwards and apparently, they were part of an online advocacy group formed to combat misogyny and homophobia in online gaming.

zeffAwesomeCon-flash.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-flash.line: Say you're glad those groups exist

zeffAwesomeCon-flash.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-flash.line: Be skeptical of that kind of awareness-raising actually working

zeffAwesomeCon-glad.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-glad.line: I'm glad those groups exist. Not that I care much about online gaming to begin with, but it's nice to know it's not all full of dudebros.

zeffAwesomeCon-skeptical.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-skeptical.line: Not to be too contrarian, but does that kind of awareness-raising actually work? I mean, the target audience seemed to not get it, so is there really much of a point?

zeffAwesomeCon-skeptical.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-skeptical.line: Activism doesn't necessarily have to change people's minds to be good for people. Sometimes, it can be used to display solidarity, and that's perfectly valid.

zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.line: I randomly bumped into that famous internet videoblog celebrity, Rob Crenshaw, also known as Parcheesi.

zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.line: And when I say bumped, I mean that literally. Needless to say, Parcheesi was pretty damn pissed.

zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.line: Wait, is he that guy in the bowler hat who talks really really fast and F-bombs every other word?

zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.line: Someone showed something of his to me once. I wasn't amused. He was trying way too hard to be funny and I just wasn't feeling it.

zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.line: Seems to be a common problem with certain men. They seem to go through life assuming they're funny when they really aren't at all.

zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.line: Point out that you're very well aware of your lack of a sense of humour

zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-parcheesi.line: Say you don't understand most men

zeffAwesomeCon-humour.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-humour.line: Well, I'll have you know that I'm very aware of my lack of a sense of humour. So there.

zeffAwesomeCon-men.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-men.line: Urgh. I can't say I understand most men, that's for sure.

zeffAwesomeCon-hand.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-hand.line: I saw this demo of a game controller shaped like a hand!

zeffAwesomeCon-hand.speaker: artemis
zeffAwesomeCon-hand.line: Really? Like, a human hand? How would that work?

zeffAwesomeCon-hand.speaker: zeff
zeffAwesomeCon-hand.line: Well, you basically wiggle the fingers around and they map to button presses. It was actually really, really creepy. Like I was fiddling with a disembodied zombie hand or something, except also trying to play Space Encroachers with it.

zeffTravel.speaker: artemis
zeffTravel.line: Do you live near here, or did you have to travel a good ways away for AwesomeCon?

zeffTravel.speaker: zeff
zeffTravel.line: I live about a 6-hour drive away, in West Denny. I try to make the trip over to Terminal City every AwesomeCon, at least.

zeffTravel.speaker: artemis
zeffTravel.line: Ah. That's further away than me, for sure. I doubt I'd even bother to go to AwesomeCon if I weren't local.

zeffTravel.speaker: zeff
zeffTravel.line: There isn't really much in the way of geek-oriented events where I am. This is pretty much as local as it gets for me. Well, unless you count the internet, which is everywhere.

zeffTravel.speaker: artemis
zeffTravel.line: Oh yes, the omnipresent internet. Can't live with it, can't live without it.

zeffMusic.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic.line: So, what do you do besides go to conventions?

zeffMusic.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic.line: I make music. Chiptunes, mostly. I turn old computers into synths and turn their bleeps and bloops into... well, still bleeps and bloops, but in a danceable rhythm of sorts.

zeffMusic.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic.line: Say you don't really listen to chiptunes, but still find it neat

zeffMusic.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic.line: Mention you never got the appeal of chiptunes

zeffMusic-neat.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-neat.line: Neat. I don't listen to a lot of chiptunes, but the stuff I have heard is fun.

zeffMusic-never.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-never.line: I never really got the nostalgic appeal of chiptunes. Maybe it's because I didn't grow up with a game console like all the other kids my age did.

zeffMusic-never.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-never.line: Videogames were really important to me, growing up. Living in a virtual world meant I could be whoever I wanted to be without dealing with the harsh reality of, well, reality.

zeffMusic-job.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-job.line: So, is chiptune music what you do for a living, then?

zeffMusic-job.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-job.line: I wish. My actual job job is filing at a doctor's office. Who knows, maybe I'll be famous as you one of these days and my hobby can finally pay off.

zeffMusic-live.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-live.line: Do you ever perform your music live?

zeffMusic-live.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-live.line: I have a couple of times, at small events for friends. I'd like to do more of that sort of thing, though.

zeffMusic-live.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-live.line: These days, performing shows for a live audience is the only way for musicians to make much of a living. You can't get discovered on the radio or whatever, anymore.

zeffMusic-live.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-live.line: That said, I know these people who are developing a videogame, and I'm trying to convince them to let me do the soundtrack. They won't be able to pay me, but it might help me land actual paid gigs in the future.

zeffMusic-listen.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-listen.line: Can I hear some of your music?

zeffMusic-listen.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-listen.line: Let Artemis hear some of your music

zeffMusic-listen.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-listen.line: Say it's not ready for public consumption yet

zeffMusic-laptop.line: A bad combination of Skrillex and Super Mario Bros.

zeffMusic-laptop.description: Subjected another human being to your music

zeffMusic-laptop.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-laptop.line: Say it's not your thing, but it's not bad

zeffMusic-laptop.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-laptop.line: Tactfully say you don't like it

zeffMusic-laptop.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-laptop.line: Honestly say you don't like it

zeffMusic-good.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-good.line: Aw, thanks! I always worry that my music isn't going to go over well with everyone, so I'm glad you actually like it!

zeffMusic-okay.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-okay.line: Well, you know, it's not really my thing, but I can hear the craft that went into it.

zeffMusic-okay.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-okay.line: Thanks! I know I have a bit of a ways to go before my music is really where I want it to be, but I appreciate the compliment.

zeffMusic-interesting.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-interesting.line: Heh. I get that all the time. I guess I'll get better with practice, huh?

zeffMusic-hated.speaker: artemis
zeffMusic-hated.line: To be honest? I hated it. Sorry.

zeffMusic-hated.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-hated.line: Well, uh, thanks for being honest. I know my music's not all the way where it needs to be to be great, but I'll keep working on it.

zeffMusic-notReady.speaker: zeff
zeffMusic-notReady.line: Well, uh... I dunno, I'm working on some stuff, but it's not really ready to show to people yet.

artemisMusic.speaker: zeff
artemisMusic.line: What kinds of music do you listen to?

artemisMusic.speaker: artemis
artemisMusic.line: Say you like just listening to ambient chatter

artemisMusic-johnCage.speaker: artemis
artemisMusic-johnCage.line: I like to hear the ambient chatter of strangers around me in public spaces.

artemisMusic-johnCage.speaker: zeff
artemisMusic-johnCage.line: Oh, so you're one of those people who listens to John Cage's 4'33'' on repeat.

artemisMusic-lol.description: Made someone laugh with a nerdy music joke

artemisMusic-huh.speaker: zeff
artemisMusic-huh.line: Well, it's this experimental music piece that basically tells the performer to be silent for four minutes and 33 seconds. The idea is, the sounds from the audience are part of the music itself.

artemisMusic-huh.speaker: zeff
artemisMusic-huh.line: Anyway, when you said you like ambient chatter, that's the first thing that came to mind.

artemisMusic-huh.description: Made a nerdy music joke and had to explain it

artemisMusic-jazz.speaker: artemis
artemisMusic-jazz.line: Well, I like jazz. Mostly from the 1940s and earlier. Back when it was music you could actually dance to, and not just a bunch of dudes showing off on stage.

artemisMusic-dance.speaker: zeff
artemisMusic-dance.line: Do you dance, then? Like, swing, or what?

artemisMusic-dance.speaker: artemis
artemisMusic-dance.line: I tried to get into swing once. I couldn't get a hang of it. I was never comfortable with the weirdly gendered lead/follow setup, you know?

artemisMusic-dance.speaker: artemis
artemisMusic-dance.line: Also admit that you're not very physically coordinated

artemisMusic-bodies.speaker: artemis
artemisMusic-bodies.line: Plus, I'm, uh, not very good at dancing. Not if it requires actual steps. I can bob in rhythm, but when my feet actually have to do things, my body just gets confused.

artemisMusic-bodies.speaker: zeff
artemisMusic-bodies.line: Bodies sure are confusing, aren't they?

artemisMusic-bodies.speaker: artemis
artemisMusic-bodies.line: I don't know. Most people seem pretty comfortable with theirs. I mostly just feel like an alien consciousness inhabiting mine.

artemisMusic-bodies.speaker: zeff
artemisMusic-bodies.line: How can you know that for sure about other people? For all you know, they're all pretending to be comfortable in their bodies but are actually all just aliens like you are.

artemisMusic-bodies.speaker: artemis
artemisMusic-bodies.line: Well, when you put it that way, maybe being comfortable with your body is just an unattainable illusion, sold to us by corporations out to profit off of our collective insecurity.

artemisMusic-bodies.speaker: zeff
artemisMusic-bodies.line: There you have it! Capitalism sure is evil.

artemisMusic-bodies.speaker: artemis
artemisMusic-bodies.line: Recall your last awful experience with capitalism

artemisJob.speaker: zeff
artemisJob.line: So... you mentioned on Twitter that your new job is taking time away from Bacteria Stories, huh?

artemisJob.speaker: artemis
artemisJob.line: Well, yeah. The rent isn't going to pay itself, and the Donate button on the site isn't really as widely-used as I'd like it to be.

artemisJob.speaker: zeff
artemisJob.line: Ask if #artemisSub#'d consider a Kickstarter campaign

artemisJob-kickstarter.speaker: zeff
artemisJob-kickstarter.line: Ever consider doing a Kickstarter campaign? Maybe that could help offset expenses.

artemisJob-kickstarter.speaker: zeff
artemisJob-kickstarter.line: And there's that other site too... Patreon, is it? I've seen a few artists use that.

artemisJob-kickstarter.speaker: artemis
artemisJob-kickstarter.line: I dunno. I've never felt comfortable outright asking people for money. It just seems like too much work to me.

artemisJob-kickstarter.speaker: zeff
artemisJob-kickstarter.line: Say you were just trying to be helpful

artemisJob-encourage.speaker: zeff
artemisJob-encourage.line: I think with a fan base like yours, you could do really well. Anyway. Think about it.

artemisJob-helpful.speaker: zeff
artemisJob-helpful.line: Sorry. I was just trying to be helpful, is all.

artemisJob-likes.speaker: zeff
artemisJob-likes.line: Well, do you like your job?

artemisJob-likes.speaker: artemis
artemisJob-likes.line: It's a job. It is what it is.

artemisJob-likes.speaker: artemis
artemisJob-likes.line: I mean, I never thought of graphic design at an advertising firm as my calling, but at least I get to make art?

artemisJob-likes.speaker: artemis
artemisJob-likes.line: Mention that you're glad you don't have to do job interviews anymore

artemisRealName.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName.line: I've been meaning to ask, is Artemis your real name?

artemisRealName.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName.line: What do you mean by real name, exactly?

artemisRealName.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName.line: It's not the name I was born with, but I do consider it my real name.

artemisRealName.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName.line: Say you meant the name #artemisSub# was born with

artemisRealName.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName.line: Say you don't get why names one gives oneself aren't real

artemisRealName.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName.line: Ask if Zeff is #zeffDet# real name

artemisRealName-born.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-born.line: Well, I meant the name you were born with.

artemisRealName-born.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-born.line: In that case, no. Artemis is a completely and utterly fake name. There. Happy?

artemisRealName-okay.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-okay.line: Say you don't get why names one gives oneself aren't real

artemisRealName-okay.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-okay.line: Ask if Zeff is #zeffDet# real name

artemisRealName-real.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-real.line: I don't get why the names we consider real are the names our parents gave us, and not the names we give ourselves.

artemisRealName-real.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-real.line: Wonder if it's because names are usually something other people use

artemisRealName-other.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-other.line: Maybe it's because names are something other people use more than you do? Just a thought.

artemisRealName-other.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-other.line: I'll have you know that I use my name just as much as anyone else.

artemisRealName-other.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-other.line: Granted, that could be because I have an inner monologue that speaks to me in the second person, but still.

artemisRealName-other.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-other.line: Ask what Artemis's inner monologue sounds like

artemisRealName-monologue.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-monologue.line: You can hear your own inner monologue? What does it sound like?

artemisRealName-monologue.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-monologue.line: Something along the lines of the following.

artemisRealName-monologue.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-monologue.line: Goodness, Artemis. You're at a big enormous fan convention, and what are you doing? You're hiding away in a coffee shop. Except you aren't really hiding anymore, because now there's this guy talking to you, and he wants to hear your inner monologue. And you're letting him. Oh, Artemis.

artemisRealName-right.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-right.line: You're right. I'm sorry. That was a really stupid question.

artemisRealName-right.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-right.line: Call out Zeff's use of ableist language

artemisRealName-ableist.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-ableist.line: 'Stupid' is an ableist word, you know.

artemisRealName-sorry.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-sorry.line: Oh god, it is, isn't it? I'm so, so sorry. I'm such an idiot...

artemisRealName-sorry.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-sorry.line: ...wait, that's ableist too, isn't it? I should really stop talking forever, shouldn't I?

artemisRealName-rephrase.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-rephrase.line: Oh, right. I meant, it was a really ignorant question.

artemisRealName-zeff.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-zeff.line: Why? Is Zeff your real name?

artemisRealName-zeff.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-zeff.line: Actually, yes. My mom liked the sound of it, and wanted to name me something more unique than Jeff.

artemisRealName-zeff.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-zeff.line: Of course, people still call me Jeff anyway, which doesn't really help.

artemisRealName-zeff.speaker: artemis
artemisRealName-zeff.line: And is that the name you'd choose for yourself if you did have a choice?

artemisRealName-zeff.speaker: zeff
artemisRealName-zeff.line: I guess? I've come to like the sound of it. But I've also had it my whole life, so there's no way of really knowing.

bacteria.speaker: zeff
bacteria.line: I feel like a total fanboy, but can I ask you some questions about Bacteria Stories?

bacteria-knock.speaker: zeff
bacteria-knock.line: Ask if Bacteria Stories is based on #artemisDet# life

bacteria-knock.speaker: zeff
bacteria-knock.line: Ask why #artemisSub# decided to do a webcomic about single-celled organisms

bacteria-knock.speaker: zeff
bacteria-knock.line: Ask if Artemis has any exciting plans for the future of Bacteria Stories

bacteria-can.speaker: artemis
bacteria-can.line: Can you ask, as in, is it physically possible for you to ask, or as in, you're asking me permission?

bacteria-can.speaker: zeff
bacteria-can.line: May I ask you some questions about Bacteria Stories?

bacteria-can.speaker: zeff
bacteria-can.line: Ask if Bacteria Stories is based on #artemisDet# life

bacteria-can.speaker: zeff
bacteria-can.line: Ask why #artemisSub# decided to do a webcomic about single-celled organisms

bacteria-can.speaker: zeff
bacteria-can.line: Ask if Artemis has any exciting plans for the future of Bacteria Stories

bacteria-life.speaker: zeff
bacteria-life.line: I've always wondered, is Bacteria Stories based on your life at all?

bacteria-life.speaker: artemis
bacteria-life.line: Well, I'm not a single-celled organism, so I wouldn't say it's anything near a direct mapping, but as with all fiction, there are some resemblances.

bacteria-life.speaker: artemis
bacteria-life.line: Anything you're curious about in particular?

bacteria-gidget.speaker: zeff
bacteria-gidget.line: Is Gidget supposed to be a stand-in for you?

bacteria-gidget.speaker: artemis
bacteria-gidget.line: Hah! Everyone seems to think that, for some reason.

bacteria-gidget.speaker: artemis
bacteria-gidget.line: While she does have a few of my characteristics, she's actually more based on a friend of mine from high school, who did the deadpan humour thing better than I ever could.

bacteria-gidget.speaker: zeff
bacteria-gidget.line: Ask if Artemis has any exciting plans for the future of Bacteria Stories

bacteria-godfrey.speaker: zeff
bacteria-godfrey.line: I was actually thinking about the strong religious undertones surrounding Godfrey the Biochemist. Was there some kind of commentary you were trying to make, there?

bacteria-godfrey.speaker: artemis
bacteria-godfrey.line: I didn't mean to make a huge statement with him, really. But I've always found it funny that most accounts of the Judeo-Christian God sound like some whiny guy in his twenties who doesn't understand that you can't force people to love you. So I thought I'd play on that a little.

bacteria-godfrey.speaker: zeff
bacteria-godfrey.line: Well, I thought it was neat how you turned it into a creation myth where Godfrey got lonely and created this pantheon of mould gods to entertain himself in an attempt to get over the manic pixie dream girl in the next lab over.

bacteria-godfrey.speaker: artemis
bacteria-godfrey.line: Thanks. I do believe that creation myths should include both monotheism and polytheism.

bacteria-godfrey.speaker: zeff
bacteria-godfrey.line: Ask if Artemis has any exciting plans for the future of Bacteria Stories

bacteria-michel.speaker: zeff
bacteria-michel.line: Seems to me like the Michel & Jacques segments are an obvious parody of a certain uber-popular webcomic about two guys sitting on a couch and talking about videogames.

bacteria-michel.speaker: artemis
bacteria-michel.line: It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure that one out, that's for sure.

bacteria-michel.speaker: zeff
bacteria-michel.line: Aren't you a little harsh on them, though, I mean, having them die in every strip they're in?

bacteria-michel.speaker: artemis
bacteria-michel.line: You could say I'm bitter about the fact that their success is built on bad rape jokes and misogyny, yeah.

bacteria-michel.speaker: zeff
bacteria-michel.line: Ask if Artemis has any exciting plans for the future of Bacteria Stories

bacteria-why.speaker: zeff
bacteria-why.line: Why did you decide to do a webcomic about single-celled organisms, anyway?

bacteria-why.speaker: artemis
bacteria-why.line: Mostly because I can't draw much of anything else, and the market for stick figures was already saturated.

bacteria-why.speaker: zeff
bacteria-why.line: Ask why Artemis even draws a webcomic at all

bacteria-why.speaker: zeff
bacteria-why.line: Say #artemisSub# can at least draw better than you

bacteria-write.speaker: zeff
bacteria-write.line: Why do a webcomic at all, then, if you don't feel strong at drawing? Why not just write instead?

bacteria-straight.speaker: artemis
bacteria-straight.line: Well, I used to doodle these bacteria-like creatures in the margins of my notes in high school, and they've kind of stuck with me since.

bacteria-straight.speaker: artemis
bacteria-straight.line: And I had stuff to say that I thought would be fun to put into a comic, so that's how it got started. The rest, as they say, is history.

bacteria-straight.speaker: artemis
bacteria-straight.line: I mean, sure, people keep complaining that my drawings look like MS Paint scribbles, but hey, I get to have fun doing it, and it's other people's loss if they don't like it.

bacteria-straight.speaker: zeff
bacteria-straight.line: Ask if Artemis has any exciting plans for the future of Bacteria Stories

bacteria-sarcastic.speaker: artemis
bacteria-sarcastic.line: Wow, like I've never heard that one before.

bacteria-sarcastic.speaker: artemis
bacteria-sarcastic.line: I don't know? Maybe I'm not really a great straight-up prose writer, either? Maybe I just really like the idea of using both words and pictures? What's it to you?

bacteria-sarcastic.speaker: zeff
bacteria-sarcastic.line: I didn't mean that, I--never mind.

bacteria-draw.speaker: zeff
bacteria-draw.line: You can certainly draw better than me, that's for sure!

bacteria-draw.speaker: artemis
bacteria-draw.line: Really, though, I used to doodle these bacteria-like creatures in the margins of my notes in high school, and they've kind of stuck with me since.

bacteria-draw.speaker: artemis
bacteria-draw.line: And I had stuff to say that I thought would be fun to put into a comic, so that's how it got started. The rest, as they say, is history.

bacteria-draw.speaker: artemis
bacteria-draw.line: I mean, sure, people keep complaining that my drawings look like MS Paint scribbles, but hey, I get to have fun doing it, and it's other people's loss if they don't like it.

bacteria-draw.speaker: zeff
bacteria-draw.line: Ask if Artemis has any exciting plans for the future of Bacteria Stories

bacteria-future.speaker: zeff
bacteria-future.line: Do you have any exciting plans for the future of Bacteria Stories?

bacteria-future.speaker: artemis
bacteria-future.line: Say that everyone will die in a war against antibiotics

bacteria-future.speaker: artemis
bacteria-future.line: Talk about your junior high spinoff idea

bacteria-future.speaker: artemis
bacteria-future.line: Talk about your murder mystery idea

bacteria-antibiotics.speaker: artemis
bacteria-antibiotics.line: I'm glad you asked! Yes. Everyone in the entire Bacteria Stories universe will die suddenly in a brutal war against antibiotics.

bacteria-antibiotics.speaker: artemis
bacteria-antibiotics.line: Heh. No. I was messing with you.

bacteria-antibiotics.speaker: artemis
bacteria-antibiotics.line: Though come to think of it, maybe one day I will end the comic that way. The more I think about it, the more I think it's kind of poetic and brilliant.

bacteria-antibiotics.speaker: zeff
bacteria-antibiotics.line: Cool! I look forward to seeing where you go with that.

bacteria-junior.speaker: artemis
bacteria-junior.line: Actually, I'm kind of thinking of doing this spinoff of Gidget and her friends in their pre-teen years, who all go to a school for astrophysically gifted bacteria kids.

bacteria-junior.speaker: artemis
bacteria-junior.line: I'm hoping to call it Neil Degrassi Tyson Junior High.

bacteria-junior.speaker: zeff
bacteria-junior.line: Cool! I look forward to seeing where you go with that.

bacteria-vladimir.speaker: artemis
bacteria-vladimir.line: I've been thinking about introducing the adventures of Vladimir the Virus and friends. They're so small that the bacteria can't see them, but introduce quite a complicating factor in the fabric of the Bacteria Stories universe.

bacteria-vladimir.speaker: zeff
bacteria-vladimir.line: Cool! I look forward to seeing where you go with that.

bacteria-mystery.speaker: artemis
bacteria-mystery.line: I kind of want to do an Agatha Christie-esque murder mystery with all these bacteria in a creepy mansion, but I want to name all the characters after Terminal City's public transit stations.

bacteria-mystery.speaker: artemis
bacteria-mystery.line: Of course, I'm probably going to want to stop introducing new characters once I hit the numbered streets.

bacteria-mystery.speaker: zeff
bacteria-mystery.line: Cool! I look forward to seeing where you go with that.

theMall.speaker: artemis
theMall.line: Speaking of capitalism, that reminds me: I actually set foot in a mall the other day.

theMall.speaker: zeff
theMall.line: Really? I don't picture you as the mall-going type at all.

theMall.speaker: artemis
theMall.line: I assure you, I'm not. But sometimes, one needs to find clothes for a big social event in order to appear as some modicum of professional.

theMall.speaker: zeff
theMall.line: Point out that AwesomeCon isn't necessarily an event where you need to look professional

theMall.speaker: zeff
theMall.line: Say you're glad your clothing purchases are mostly t-shirts off the internet

theMall.speaker: artemis
theMall.line: Talk about how the shopping trip went

theMall-professional.speaker: zeff
theMall-professional.line: I wouldn't say AwesomeCon is necessarily an event where you need to look professional. The dress code is pretty much t-shirts and jeans if you aren't cosplaying.

theMall-professional.speaker: artemis
theMall-professional.line: Say your jeans had holes in the crotch

theMall-professional.speaker: artemis
theMall-professional.line: Say you meant your new job, not just AwesomeCon

theMall-holes.speaker: artemis
theMall-holes.line: Well, my jeans had embarrassing holes in the crotch, and as you can imagine, I don't feel comfortable displaying my underwear to this crowd.

theMall-holes.speaker: artemis
theMall-holes.line: Talk about how the shopping trip went

theMall-newJob.speaker: artemis
theMall-newJob.line: I meant clothes for my new job, not just for AwesomeCon. The whole business casual thing is still pretty new to me.

theMall-newJob.speaker: artemis
theMall-newJob.line: Talk about how the shopping trip went

theMall-tShirts.speaker: zeff
theMall-tShirts.line: Well, I'm glad the majority of my clothing purchases are t-shirts off the internet.

theMall-tShirts.speaker: artemis
theMall-tShirts.line: Oh, believe me, mine would be too if most t-shirts I bought off the internet didn't awkwardly stretch in the chest area.

theMall-tShirts.speaker: artemis
theMall-tShirts.line: Talk about how the shopping trip went

theMall-howItWent.speaker: artemis
theMall-howItWent.line: Anyway, it felt like every store I went to just... didn't want me there. All the women's clothes were super duper femme and meant for much skinnier people than me.

theMall-howItWent.speaker: artemis
theMall-howItWent.line: I tried on stuff in the men's section too, because they looked more like things I'd actually wear. But when I put them on, they'd be too big in some areas and not big enough in others.

theMall-howItWent.speaker: artemis
theMall-howItWent.line: In the end, I found some neutral-enough things that fit me in the middle-aged women's section at the department store. Success?

theMall-howItWent.speaker: zeff
theMall-howItWent.line: Talk about how you usually have the opposite sorts of problems when going clothes shopping

theMall-howItWent.speaker: zeff
theMall-howItWent.line: Chime in that hopefully #artemisSub# won't have to go back to the mall for a while

theMall-howItWent.speaker: zeff
theMall-howItWent.line: Ask if #artemisSub# ever tried shopping at thrift stores instead

theMall-opposite.speaker: zeff
theMall-opposite.line: Heh, I have kind of the opposite problem. I hate everything in the men's section. It's all so drab and boring and usually too big for me.

theMall-opposite.speaker: zeff
theMall-opposite.line: I like the variety and colours and fun patterns in the women's section, but I'm always nervous that people are going to look at me funny if I try anything on.

theMall-opposite.speaker: artemis
theMall-opposite.line: Rant about your problems with women's clothing

theMall-opposite.speaker: artemis
theMall-opposite.line: Muse about your ideal gender neutral clothing retailer

theMall-womensClothing.speaker: artemis
theMall-womensClothing.line: The problem I have with women's clothing is, it's meant to go out of fashion by next season because they want you to keep buying more clothes. And it's all so shoddily made and falls apart if you wear anything with any regularity.

theMall-womensClothing.speaker: artemis
theMall-womensClothing.line: At least with men's clothes, they're well-made and rugged. You can get by on a limited wardrobe of just a few pieces, because the styles are more timeless. Plus, they tend to have actual pockets and stuff, which is super handy.

theMall-womensClothing.speaker: zeff
theMall-womensClothing.line: Men's clothes are well-made? That's not really my experience at all. I've had a lot of stuff that's ripped or had holes in them and stuff.

theMall-womensClothing.speaker: zeff
theMall-womensClothing.line: And as for having a limited wardrobe, well, all that really does is makes everyone look the same. The last thing I want to be is a corporate drone in a suit.

theMall-womensClothing.speaker: artemis
theMall-womensClothing.line: And I want to find a suit that actually fits me, one of these days.

theMall-womensClothing.speaker: zeff
theMall-womensClothing.line: I think you'd look good in a well-fitted suit. I, on the other hand, look like the most awkward Jehovah's witness.

theMall-womensClothing.speaker: artemis
theMall-womensClothing.line: Hesitantly thank Zeff for the compliment

theMall-thanksIGuess.speaker: zeff
theMall-thanksIGuess.line: Ask if #artemisSub# ever tried shopping at thrift stores instead

theMall-genderNeutral.speaker: artemis
theMall-genderNeutral.line: See, this is exactly why I'd love a clothing retailer that was completely gender neutral and had the same things available for all body types.

theMall-genderNeutral.speaker: zeff
theMall-genderNeutral.line: But then, how would they enforce the gender binary? That just wouldn't be profitable for their bottom line!

theMall-genderNeutral.speaker: artemis
theMall-genderNeutral.line: Well, they'd have people like me actually enjoy buying clothes to wear, which you'd think would translate to more sales. But what do I know? Corporations never take my perspective into account.

theMall-genderNeutral.speaker: zeff
theMall-genderNeutral.line: Oh, I'm totally with you there. Except I'd also want to make sure they didn't use sweat shops, because exploitation is just gross.

theMall-genderNeutral.speaker: artemis
theMall-genderNeutral.line: Oh, definitely. Locally-sourced clothing does get pretty expensive, though. I wonder if our generation's badly paying jobs can actually keep up with that.

theMall-genderNeutral.speaker: zeff
theMall-genderNeutral.line: Ask if #artemisSub# ever tried shopping at thrift stores instead

theMall-hopefully.speaker: zeff
theMall-hopefully.line: Well, hopefully you got enough clothes that you won't have to go back for a while.

theMall-hopefully.speaker: artemis
theMall-hopefully.line: Probably, unless they fall apart in the next two months. Even then, at least I know what size I am and can order duplicates off the internet, maybe.

theMall-hopefully.speaker: zeff
theMall-hopefully.line: Ask if #artemisSub# ever tried shopping at thrift stores instead

theMall-thrift.speaker: zeff
theMall-thrift.line: Have you ever tried shopping at thrift stores instead?

theMall-thrift.speaker: artemis
theMall-thrift.line: Sometimes. I can't get everything I want there, though, because I'm sensitive to the musty smell of previously-worn clothing.

theMall-thrift.speaker: artemis
theMall-thrift.line: I did find a cool army jacket, once. And a corduroy vest. But for things like shirts and pants and stuff, I'm mostly out of luck.

theMall-thrift.speaker: zeff
theMall-thrift.line: That's too bad. I really like thrift stores. Sometimes, you can find some really awesome things in there for, uh, costumes and stuff.

jobInterviews.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews.line: That reminds me, I'm so glad I don't have to do job interviews anymore. Those things are almost as bad as a visit to the dentist's office.

jobInterviews.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews.line: Say that you actually like going to the dentist's office

jobInterviews.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews.line: Say that job interviews make you really nervous

jobInterviews.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews.line: Rant about how annoying the questions are

jobInterviews.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews.line: Rant about how you hate having to pretend to be passionate

jobInterviews.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews.line: Rant about how chafing the corporate world is

jobInterviews-dentist.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-dentist.line: You know, I actually like going to the dentist's office. It brings back happy memories of getting my picture on the No Cavities Club wall and getting a toothbrush and a little box of dental floss to take home.

jobInterviews-dentist.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-dentist.line: You must have had the best dentist ever. I'm envious. Anyway, what was I talking about before? Oh yeah, job interviews.

jobInterviews-dentist.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-dentist.line: Rant about how annoying the questions are

jobInterviews-dentist.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-dentist.line: Rant about how you hate having to pretend to be passionate

jobInterviews-dentist.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-dentist.line: Rant about how chafing the corporate world is

jobInterviews-nervous.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-nervous.line: Yeah. Job interviews make me really nervous. I'm always scared I'm going to flub them up completely.

jobInterviews-nervous.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-nervous.line: Rant about how annoying the questions are

jobInterviews-nervous.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-nervous.line: Rant about how you hate having to pretend to be passionate

jobInterviews-nervous.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-nervous.line: Rant about how chafing the corporate world is

jobInterviews-questions.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-questions.line: I'm always so annoyed by the questions they ask. Like, where do I see myself in five years? The hell if I know. And what is my biggest weakness? Everyone knows that's actually supposed to be something that can be seen as a strength.

jobInterviews-questions.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-questions.line: And asking me why manhole covers are round? What does that even have to do with anything? As far as I'm aware, my job isn't going to involve engineering manhole covers.

jobInterviews-questions.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-questions.line: Point out that some of those questions test things other than the straight answers

jobInterviews-questions.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-questions.line: Suggest that manhole covers are round so that the Ninja Turtles can fit through them

jobInterviews-test.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-test.line: Some of those questions are testing things other than your answers to them. Like how you can think on your feet. Or how you react under pressure.

jobInterviews-test.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-test.line: I guess you can say that the way I react under pressure is to question the pointlessness of it all. And I highly doubt that would endear me to the interviewers.

jobInterviews-ninja.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-ninja.line: Aren't manhole covers round so that the Ninja Turtles can fit through them? That's what I always thought.

jobInterviews-ninja.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-ninja.line: You know, the Ninja Turtles are old enough that interviewers might actually find that joke funny. Don't know how much that will help with the getting hired part, though.

jobInterviews-ninja.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-ninja.line: Well, if you crack the right jokes, maybe they'll decide you're a good fit for the company culture.

jobInterviews-ninja.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-ninja.line: Maybe. I already got hired, though, so it's kind of a moot point.

jobInterviews-passion.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-passion.line: I hate how you always have to make yourself look so passionate about doing whatever menial work they want you to be doing. I mean, it's a job, and I can do it. They know it, and I know it. Why can't we just drop all pretense of caring?

jobInterviews-passion.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-passion.line: I don't know. What if there's another person interviewing for the job who actually does feel that it's their passion in life?

jobInterviews-passion.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-passion.line: Question what it even means to have a passion in life

jobInterviews-passion.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-passion.line: Argue that most people are full of shit about that sort of thing

jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.line: What does it even mean to have a passion in life? Life feels way too complicated and unknown for that. To limit your passion for life to your job just seems way too disingenuous to me. Like it's just asking to be taken advantage of.

jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.line: I don't know. You can be passionate about your job and also passionate about other things, thus making you a well-rounded person. Passion isn't a finite resource.

jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.line: Really? Some people think it is. Especially if they work in upper management. The way you hear them talk, it's like if you do anything other than work, then it's taking away time that you could be working.

jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.line: That's a load of bunk. Haven't they done studies to prove that people can only work 40 hours a week before productivity takes a nosedive?

jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.line: I don't know. Somehow, they think that they're more superhuman than that. And that everyone else should be. I don't know what to make of it.

jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-whatIsPassion.line: Ask what superpower Artemis would have, if #artemisSub# had one

jobInterviews-bullshit.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-bullshit.line: Good for them, I guess. But most people are full of shit about that sort of thing. It's a game of who can bullshit the best. And it's, well, bullshit.

jobInterviews-chafing.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-chafing.line: The corporate world is so uncomfortably chafing. All those handshakes and all that doublespeak and all those made-up corporatese words. I wish they'd be a bit more real.

jobInterviews-chafing.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-chafing.line: Well, a lot more real. But I'm willing to settle for a little bit.

jobInterviews-chafing.speaker: zeff
jobInterviews-chafing.line: Well, now that you have a job, don't you still have to deal with the corporate world?

jobInterviews-chafing.speaker: artemis
jobInterviews-chafing.line: I do, and I still hate it. But at least now I'm being paid to have to deal with it. Not like while I was interviewing and had to make a show of impressing them just so they'd hire me.

roadTrip.speaker: zeff
roadTrip.line: The road trip over here was a lot of fun.

roadTrip.speaker: artemis
roadTrip.line: Oh yeah? What was fun about it?

roadTrip.speaker: zeff
roadTrip.line: Well, I drove here with my friends, Sparrow and Robin. They're a married couple, kind of older than me, and Sparrow runs a tabletop RPG that I'm part of, so that's how we know each other.

roadTrip.speaker: artemis
roadTrip.line: Ask if they both have bird names on purpose

roadTrip.speaker: artemis
roadTrip.line: Ask what a tabletop RPG is

roadTrip.speaker: zeff
roadTrip.line: Continue talking about the road trip

roadTrip-birds.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-birds.line: Sparrow and Robin, huh? Do they both have bird names on purpose?

roadTrip-birds.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-birds.line: I don't think so. Well, I know Sparrow changed his name legally from something more conventional sounding, but I think that happened before he met Robin. And Robin, as far as I know, was always named Robin.

roadTrip-birds.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-birds.line: But they call their house the Rookery, and decorate their house with bird things, so I guess they just took that coincidence and ran with it.

roadTrip-birds.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-birds.line: Bring the conversation back to the road trip

roadTrip-tabletop.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-tabletop.line: Role-playing game. You sit around the table, tell a story together, and occasionally roll dice to decide how things turn out.

roadTrip-tabletop.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-tabletop.line: Usually, there are snacks on hand, traditionally of the junk food variety, though Sparrow and Robin aren't into junk food, so we get things like artisanal cheeses and homemade coconut milk ice cream instead.

roadTrip-tabletop.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-tabletop.line: Basically, Sparrow's created this universe where everyone has superpowers, and every character's power is connected to a single element. And we must use these powers to fight against ignorance and hegemonic power structures.

roadTrip-tabletop.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-tabletop.line: Elements? So, like, earth, wind, fire, water, and heart?

roadTrip-tabletop.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-tabletop.line: No, I mean elements from the periodic table. My character controls phosphorus. I originally wanted krypton, but noble gases turned out not to work very well with the stats balancing system.

roadTrip-tabletop.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-tabletop.line: Bring the conversation back to the road trip

roadTrip-veruca.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-veruca.line: Anyway, so, the road trip. We decided to have lunch in this restaurant and pub-type place inside a super gaudy tourist-trap hotel.

roadTrip-veruca.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-veruca.line: It was called the Chateau Veruca. I don't know if you're familiar with it?

roadTrip-veruca.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-veruca.line: Say you might have passed by on family trips when you were little

roadTrip-family.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-family.line: I think I might have passed by that place on family trips we took when I was a little kid? But I've never been inside.

roadTrip-family.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-family.line: Well, it's practically in the middle of nowhere, and it's famous for having these ridiculous theme rooms.

roadTrip-family.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-family.line: There's a French Renaissance castle room, a 1930s gangster mafia room, a medieval monastery room, a Cold War-era retro-futuristic spaceship room, an Ancient Roman gladiator room, a Crimean War hospital room, and a Titanic room...

roadTrip-family.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-family.line: ...apparently, that last one was specifically built at an angle to simulate the sinking ship.

roadTrip-family.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-family.line: Say that sounds really impressive and really awful at the same time

roadTrip-family.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-family.line: Explain about the restaurant and pub where you ate

roadTrip-nope.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-nope.line: Well, it's practically in the middle of nowhere, and it's famous for having these ridiculous theme rooms.

roadTrip-nope.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-nope.line: There's a French Renaissance castle room, a 1930s gangster mafia room, a medieval monastery room, a Cold War-era retro-futuristic spaceship room, an Ancient Roman gladiator room, a Crimean War hospital room, and a Titanic room...

roadTrip-nope.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-nope.line: ...apparently, that last one was specifically built at an angle to simulate the sinking ship.

roadTrip-nope.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-nope.line: Say that sounds really impressive and really awful at the same time

roadTrip-nope.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-nope.line: Explain about the restaurant and pub where you ate

roadTrip-awful.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-awful.line: Wow. That sounds really impressive and really awful at the same time. How do they stay in business?

roadTrip-awful.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-awful.line: I think the owners are a super duper rich old-money family or something. Their budget's practically unlimited.

roadTrip-awful.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-awful.line: And the hotel's a surprisingly popular vacation destination for people living out in the boonies, so it's not like they're losing much in the way of money, either.

roadTrip-awful.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-awful.line: Explain about the restaurant and pub where you ate

roadTrip-awful.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-awful.line: Ask how the rest of the road trip went

roadTrip-pub.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-pub.line: So, the restaurant and pub. It couldn't decide whether it wanted to be a 1950s malt shop diner or an Old West saloon, so it was this weird mix of waitresses in poodle skirts and cowboy hats serving sarsaparilla milkshakes.

roadTrip-pub.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-pub.line: But they also have this famous policy of being rude to customers on purpose. Like, if you don't finish all the food on your plate, they make fun of you and force you donate the cost of the wasted food to starving kids in Africa.

roadTrip-pub.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-pub.line: Say you'd actually find rudeness kind of refreshing

roadTrip-pub.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-pub.line: Say that the donation thing sounds like a good idea

roadTrip-pub.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-pub.line: Ask how the rest of the road trip went

roadTrip-rudeness.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-rudeness.line: You know, it's weird, but I'd find that kind of refreshing. I hate how service industry people are so polite to the point that I feel like they're actively bothering me. It feels so insincere and forced.

roadTrip-rudeness.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-rudeness.line: Well, it felt a bit forced there, too, in that a lot of the staff didn't really want to be rude but were just following a script.

roadTrip-rudeness.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-rudeness.line: Sparrow and Robin mostly found it annoying rather than funny, but we were all kind of tired from driving, so maybe it would be more fun under better circumstances. I don't know.

roadTrip-rudeness.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-rudeness.line: Ask how the rest of the road trip went

roadTrip-africa.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-africa.line: Actually, the donation thing sounds like a good idea. When I was a kid, my parents used the starving kids in Africa line on me, and I recall asking them on more than one occasion why I couldn't just mail them my leftovers.

roadTrip-africa.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-africa.line: Of course, back then, I had no concept of food spoiling, but still.

roadTrip-africa.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-africa.line: Yeah. But then, sometimes it's hard to tell where the money's really going, when it comes to those sorts of charities.

roadTrip-africa.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-africa.line: Robin actually looked up the name of the charity listed on the menu, and apparently, it's one of those Christian organisations that's super homophobic.

roadTrip-africa.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-africa.line: Neither of us felt comfortable donating there, and they didn't give us any other options. So much for that.

roadTrip-africa.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-africa.line: Ask how the rest of the road trip went

roadTrip-theRest.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-theRest.line: How was the rest of your road trip?

roadTrip-theRest.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-theRest.line: Oh, we played a lot of car games. I had them pretty stumped when we were playing Botticelli and I picked MC Frontalot.

roadTrip-theRest.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-theRest.line: Of course, once it got late, we devolved into the Anal Game.

roadTrip-botticelli.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-botticelli.line: I've never played Botticelli. How does that one go?

roadTrip-botticelli.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-botticelli.line: Okay, so one player thinks of a famous person and tells the other players what the first letter of said famous person's name is. Then, everyone else has to ask a question, the answer to which must start with the letter mentioned.

roadTrip-botticelli.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-botticelli.line: For example, say I pick Steve Jobs. Then you would ask me a question where the answer starts with a J, such as, what do you call a drink made out of fruit? If I correctly answer juice, then the next person asks me another question.

roadTrip-botticelli.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-botticelli.line: If I get stumped, you get to ask me a direct question about the person I chose, like am I bald? And then you keep doing that until someone guesses Steve Jobs.

roadTrip-anal.speaker: artemis
roadTrip-anal.line: Anal Game? I'm almost afraid to ask.

roadTrip-anal.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-anal.line: Oh, it's really juvenile. You take the names of passing cars and add Anal to them with hilarious results. Like for instance, Anal Safari, Anal Escape, Anal Probe, Anal Windstar, that sort of thing.

roadTrip-anal.speaker: zeff
roadTrip-anal.line: It's funniest with American-made cars, not so much with German or Japanese ones. Anal Corolla and Anal X5 just don't have the same ring to them.

roadTrip-anal.description: Eww, toilet humour? What are you, five?

superpower.speaker: zeff
superpower.line: So, riddle me this. If you had a superpower, what would it be?

superpower.speaker: artemis
superpower.line: Do you mean, what superpower do I wish I had, or what superpower do I actually have?

superpower.speaker: zeff
superpower.line: Say the one Artemis wishes #artemisSub# had

superpower.speaker: zeff
superpower.line: Say the one Artemis actually has

superpower-wish.speaker: zeff
superpower-wish.line: The one you wish you had.

superpower-telekinesis.speaker: zeff
superpower-telekinesis.line: Interesting choice! And why is that?

superpower-telekinesis.speaker: artemis
superpower-telekinesis.line: Well, the ability to move objects with one's mind is by far the coolest thing ever, and would make a lot of things in life so much easier. Not to mention completely freak out your enemies.

superpower-telekinesis.speaker: artemis
superpower-telekinesis.line: Then again, it could be that I read Roald Dahl's Matilda one too many times as a kid. And now that I think about it, Stephen King's Carrie probably made an impression as well...

superpower-telekinesis.speaker: artemis
superpower-telekinesis.line: Ask what superpower Zeff wishes #zeffSub# had

superpower-immortality.speaker: zeff
superpower-immortality.line: Really? I wouldn't want to be immortal. I'd feel like eventually, I'd just want to die already, especially if my health were failing.

superpower-immortality.speaker: artemis
superpower-immortality.line: Well, since I'd be superpowered and all, I'd assume I'd still be in perfect health the whole time.

superpower-immortality.speaker: zeff
superpower-immortality.line: Yeah, but still. Wouldn't you be interested in knowing what happens after you die?

superpower-immortality.speaker: artemis
superpower-immortality.line: Not really. As far as the best evidence shows, what happens is that you absolutely cease to exist.

superpower-immortality.speaker: artemis
superpower-immortality.line: Meanwhile, there's so much to do here in this world that you can't spend an entire lifetime doing it. I mean, if I were immortal, I could read every book ever published and learn every skill there was to learn. And I wouldn't even come close to running out of material.

superpower-immortality.speaker: artemis
superpower-immortality.line: Elaborate on why you don't believe in the supernatural

superpower-immortality.speaker: artemis
superpower-immortality.line: Ask what superpower Zeff wishes #zeffSub# had

superpower-zeff.speaker: artemis
superpower-zeff.line: Why? What superpower do you wish you had?

superpower-zeff.speaker: zeff
superpower-zeff.line: Honestly, I've always wanted to be able to fly. Now that would be really cool.

superpower-zeff.speaker: zeff
superpower-zeff.line: Sometimes, I have dreams where I'm flying up in the air and amidst the clouds, and it's so beautiful and amazing and freeing that when I wake up, I'm sad that it wasn't real.

superpower-zeff.speaker: artemis
superpower-zeff.line: I don't know. I think that would freak me out. I'm scared of heights, and I think I'd be too terrified of getting hit by something and falling to actually exercise my flying superpower.

superpower-zeff.speaker: zeff
superpower-zeff.line: But the point of the superpower is that you wouldn't have to be scared because you'd already be good at dodging obstacles and stuff. It's not really suppposed to be a practical exercise.

superpower-actually.speaker: artemis
superpower-actually.line: Say you've never really considered yourself superpowered

superpower-actually.speaker: artemis
superpower-actually.line: Say that your superpower is invisibility

superpower-mundane.speaker: artemis
superpower-mundane.line: Well, I've never really considered myself superpowered. I'm more of a mundane human. It's boring, I know, but it's true.

superpower-mundane.speaker: zeff
superpower-mundane.line: Oh, come on, there's got to be something. For instance, I've got a ridiculously good memory for numbers. I once memorised pi to five hundred decimal places.

superpower-demonstration.speaker: artemis
superpower-demonstration.line: Oh yeah? Care to give me a demonstration?

superpower-demonstration.speaker: zeff
superpower-demonstration.line: Okay... Three point one four one five nine two six five three five eight nine seven nine...

superpower-demonstration.speaker: artemis
superpower-demonstration.line: Be impressed and kind of shocked

superpower-demonstration.speaker: artemis
superpower-demonstration.line: Ask how you know he's not making all that up

superpower-demonstration.speaker: zeff
superpower-demonstration.line: Three two three eight four six two six four three three eight three two seven nine...

superpower-demonstration.speaker: zeff
superpower-demonstration.line: Five zero two eight eight four one seven nine six nine three nine nine three seven five...

superpower-demonstration.speaker: zeff
superpower-demonstration.line: One zero five eight two zero nine seven four nine four four five nine two three zero...

superpower-demonstration.speaker: zeff
superpower-demonstration.line: Seven eight one six four zero six two eight six two zero eight nine nine eight six two eight zero...

superpower-demonstration.speaker: zeff
superpower-demonstration.line: Three four eight two five three four two one one seven zero six seven nine eight two one four eight...

superpower-demonstration.speaker: zeff
superpower-demonstration.line: Zero eight six five one three two eight two three zero six six four seven zero nine three eight... four? Aw crap, I lost it.

superpower-wow.speaker: artemis
superpower-wow.line: Okay, okay, wow. That's enough. I believe you.

superpower-wow.speaker: artemis
superpower-wow.line: Ask if he's really into math

superpower-faking.speaker: artemis
superpower-faking.line: Wait a minute, how do I know you're not making all that up?

superpower-faking.speaker: zeff
superpower-faking.line: Well, you can't really make up strings of random numbers on the spot. It's impossible. After a while, you just start repeating yourself, unless you memorise some numbers ahead of time. So I say, why not just remember the actual numbers?

superpower-faking.speaker: artemis
superpower-faking.line: Ask if he's really into math

superpower-math.speaker: artemis
superpower-math.line: So, are you like really into math, then?

superpower-math.speaker: zeff
superpower-math.line: Not really. I mean, I was okay at it in high school, but I didn't go so far as to major in math or anything like that. I just figured out I have a good memory for numbers, and I wanted to challenge myself to memorise pi just to see if I could do it.

superpower-math.speaker: zeff
superpower-math.line: As it turns out, it's really just like remembering a bunch of phone numbers in order.

superpower-math.speaker: artemis
superpower-math.line: Yeah, but people don't even do that anymore, now that we all have smartphones that can remember numbers way better than we can.

superpower-noNeed.speaker: artemis
superpower-noNeed.line: I guess I probably shouldn't ask you for a demonstration, or else we'll be here all night, won't we?

superpower-noNeed.speaker: zeff
superpower-noNeed.line: Most people make me shut up after about twenty. That's still more than most engineers say is necessary for practical applications of pi. Oh well.

superpower-segue.speaker: zeff
superpower-segue.line: Anyway, we were going to talk about your superpower, weren't we?

superpower-segue.speaker: artemis
superpower-segue.line: Say that your superpower is invisibility

superpower-invisibility.speaker: artemis
superpower-invisibility.line: Yeah. Hmm. I guess it would have to be invisibility. But it doesn't really make me feel powerful. It feels more like something out of my control.

superpower-invisibility.speaker: zeff
