superpower-invisibility.line: Say you sometimes feel like you'd want to be invisible

superpower-zeffInvisible.speaker: zeff
superpower-zeffInvisible.line: Sometimes, I feel like it would be nice to be invisible for a change. That way, I could look and act however I wanted and no one would ever bother me for it.

superpower-zeffInvisible.speaker: artemis
superpower-zeffInvisible.line: Are you saying I should be taking more advantage of my superpower, then?

superpower-zeffInvisible.speaker: zeff
superpower-zeffInvisible.line: I'm not saying anything about you. I'm just...

superpower-zeffInvisible.speaker: zeff
superpower-zeffInvisible.line: I feel like I'm under constant surveillance, you know? Like if I deviate too far out of my prescribed role as a supposedly normal-looking white man, everyone will turn on me.

superpower-zeffInvisible.speaker: zeff
superpower-zeffInvisible.line: Suggest that maybe Zeff's been reading too much Foucault

superpower-foucault.speaker: artemis
superpower-foucault.line: Sounds like someone's been reading too much Foucault lately.

superpower-foucault.description: Made a reference to Foucault's Panopticon

superpower-foucault.speaker: zeff
superpower-foucault.line: I'm not really familiar with Foucault. Did he write dystopian sci-fi?

superpower-foucault.speaker: artemis
superpower-foucault.line: Well, now that you mention it, if aliens got their hands on some of Foucault's writing, they'd probably find it grotesquely fascinating in a dystopian sci-fi sense. So, sure.

cyclists.speaker: artemis
cyclists.line: I almost got hit by a car on my bike ride over here.

cyclists.speaker: zeff
cyclists.line: Express amazement that #artemisSub# rode #artemisDet# bike here

cyclists-scared.speaker: zeff
cyclists-scared.line: You rode your bike here? Wow. I'd be scared to ride a bike in Terminal City traffic. Like, seriously.

cyclists-scared.speaker: artemis
cyclists-scared.line: Say you ride your bike pretty much everywhere and are used to it

cyclists-scared.speaker: artemis
cyclists-scared.line: Tell the story about that asshole who almost hit you with his car

cyclists-careful.speaker: zeff
cyclists-careful.line: Yikes! That's awful! I know how aggressive those Terminal City drivers can be. I hope you're being careful.

cyclists-careful.speaker: artemis
cyclists-careful.line: Say you ride your bike pretty much everywhere and are used to it

cyclists-careful.speaker: artemis
cyclists-careful.line: Tell the story about that asshole who almost hit you with his car

cyclists-usedToIt.speaker: artemis
cyclists-usedToIt.line: Yeah, I'm used to it. I've been riding my bike pretty much everywhere lately. I can't afford a car, and public transit around here is pretty damn slow.

cyclists-usedToIt.speaker: zeff
cyclists-usedToIt.line: Yeah, having a car and living in Terminal City is pretty expensive, I guess.

cyclists-usedToIt.speaker: artemis
cyclists-usedToIt.line: Tell the story about that asshole who almost hit you with his car

cyclists-asshole.speaker: artemis
cyclists-asshole.line: Anyway, the guy in the car that almost hit me starts yelling at me for going too slow and being in the way or whatever. He's all like, learn to ride, dumbass. And I wasn't doing anything wrong!

cyclists-asshole.speaker: artemis
cyclists-asshole.line: So, of course, as he passes, I flip him the bird, because he's being an asshole. And then, get this, he stops. And starts driving in reverse towards me.

cyclists-asshole.speaker: artemis
cyclists-asshole.line: I'm totally freaked out, so I ride into a side street to avoid him, and then -- what the hell -- he follows me. Starts calling me a fucking bitch. I was in so much shock that I just let him continue yelling at me until he finally decided to leave.

cyclists-asshole.speaker: zeff
cyclists-asshole.line: Agree that the guy was an asshole

cyclists-asshole.speaker: zeff
cyclists-asshole.line: Say that of course the driver's going to get even more pissed off if you flip him the bird

cyclists-asshole.speaker: artemis
cyclists-asshole.line: Point out the hilarity in the driver going out of his way when he was already in a hurry

cyclists-asshole.speaker: artemis
cyclists-asshole.line: Say it seems like drivers in this city are getting angrier and angrier at cyclists

cyclists-wow.speaker: zeff
cyclists-wow.line: Wow. You said it: what an asshole.

cyclists-wow.speaker: artemis
cyclists-wow.line: Point out the hilarity in the driver going out of his way when he was already in a hurry

cyclists-wow.speaker: artemis
cyclists-wow.line: Say it seems like drivers in this city are getting angrier and angrier at cyclists

cyclists-ofCourse.speaker: zeff
cyclists-ofCourse.line: You flipped the bird at an already pissed off driver? Of course he's going to get even more pissed off.

cyclists-ofCourse.speaker: artemis
cyclists-ofCourse.line: Point out the hilarity in the driver going out of his way when he was already in a hurry

cyclists-ofCourse.speaker: artemis
cyclists-ofCourse.line: Say it seems like drivers in this city are getting angrier and angrier at cyclists

cyclists-hilarity.speaker: artemis
cyclists-hilarity.line: The hilarious thing is, he was angry at me in the first place because he was in a hurry, but he goes out of his way to stop, turn into a side street, and yell at me? Won't that make him even more late to wherever it is he's trying to get to? Sheesh.

cyclists-hilarity.speaker: artemis
cyclists-hilarity.line: Say it seems like drivers in this city are getting angrier and angrier at cyclists

cyclists-angrier.speaker: artemis
cyclists-angrier.line: You know, it really seems like drivers in this city are getting angrier and angrier, now that bike commuting is becoming more of a popular means of transport. It's like they have it in for us or something.

cyclists-angrier.speaker: zeff
cyclists-angrier.line: Point out that you see a lot of reckless cyclists on the road

cyclists-angrier.speaker: zeff
cyclists-angrier.line: Point out that we're all used to cars in cities and not bicycles

cyclists-reckless.speaker: zeff
cyclists-reckless.line: Well, I'm not saying you do this, but I see a lot of reckless cyclists on the road. Running red lights and blowing right through stop signs, that sort of thing. I'd get angry at anyone not following the rules of the road.

cyclists-reckless.speaker: artemis
cyclists-reckless.line: Yeah, I try to follow the rules of the road as best as I can, but the fact is, the rules were made for drivers, and so were the roads themselves, and it's not really fair to hold cyclists to the same standard.

cyclists-reckless.speaker: artemis
cyclists-reckless.line: See, when a cyclist comes to a complete stop and puts their foot down, it takes a lot of time to accelerate back to full speed again. It's like if a driver had to put the car in park, open the door, and check their blind spots at every stop sign. That would just hold up traffic.

cyclists-reckless.description: Lectured someone on the fine points of urban cycling

cyclists-reckless.speaker: artemis
cyclists-reckless.line: They should just enact one of those laws that allows bikes to make rolling stops at intersections. That would make things a lot better.

cyclists-reckless.speaker: zeff
cyclists-reckless.line: Say that Artemis makes a good point

cyclists-reckless.speaker: zeff
cyclists-reckless.line: Protest that special laws for cyclists might confuse drivers and cause more accidents

cyclists-goodPoint.speaker: zeff
cyclists-goodPoint.line: That's a good point. If the roads were friendlier to both drivers and cyclists, we'd have a lot fewer problems.

cyclists-confuse.speaker: zeff
cyclists-confuse.line: Wouldn't drivers get confused if they see bikes not stopping at stop signs? Wouldn't that be too unpredictable and cause more accidents?

cyclists-confuse.speaker: zeff
cyclists-confuse.line: Also, if you allow bikes to not make a complete stop, what's stopping them from not slowing down at all and just blasting at full speed into the intersection?

cyclists-confuse.speaker: artemis
cyclists-confuse.line: See, the thing is, regardless of the law, cyclists already behave this way. The law would just be codifying what already happens naturally. And would, ideally, give stiffer penalties to drivers for hitting cyclists.

cyclists-confuse.speaker: zeff
cyclists-confuse.line: I don't really see how stiffer penalties for drivers will go over well.

cyclists-confuse.speaker: artemis
cyclists-confuse.line: Well, let's put it this way. Cars can actually kill people. Bikes, not so much. Drivers are the ones with the most privilege. Ergo, they should be the ones held accountable. End of story.

cyclists-cars.speaker: zeff
cyclists-cars.line: Well, we're all so used to cars in cities and not so used to bicycles. Most people don't respond well to change.

cyclists-cars.speaker: artemis
cyclists-cars.line: Maybe, but in this case, change is necessary. Since the recession's happened, people just can't afford cars as much anymore.

cyclists-cars.speaker: artemis
cyclists-cars.line: Plus, the environment's going down the toilet and if we keep doing what we're doing, this earth won't even be habitable anymore.

cyclists-cars.speaker: zeff
cyclists-cars.line: Ask if Artemis thinks you're a bad person for driving a car

cyclists-cars.speaker: zeff
cyclists-cars.line: Argue that you actually need a car because of where you live

cyclists-badGuy.speaker: zeff
cyclists-badGuy.line: You don't think I'm a bad person for driving a car, do you?

cyclists-badGuy.speaker: artemis
cyclists-badGuy.line: No, I never said that. I mean, people have their reasons for needing to drive. I don't judge individuals. I'm just worried about the big picture, is all.

cyclists-need.speaker: zeff
cyclists-need.line: If it were possible for me to not have to drive a car, I'd get rid of mine. But I live all the way in Denny, and if I don't have a car, I'm practically stuck at home. Not everyone's able to live in a densely populated city.

cyclists-need.speaker: artemis
cyclists-need.line: Right, and please know that I'm not judging you specifically. If you have your reasons, they're your reasons. I'm just worried about the big picture, is all.

terminalCity.speaker: artemis
terminalCity.line: It feels kinda weird that this city's become so friendly, since AwesomeCon's been happening. You don't really see people wandering around being nice to each other on a regular day, that's for sure.

terminalCity.speaker: zeff
terminalCity.line: Well, since I only come here for AwesomeCon, it feels like it's like this all the time. How is it usually like?

terminalCity.speaker: artemis
terminalCity.line: Enh. People mostly keep to themselves, I guess. Especially in the winter months, when it's grey and raining all the time. Sometimes, I feel like Terminal City suffers from collective seasonal affective disorder.

terminalCity.speaker: artemis
terminalCity.line: And I mean, even if you do have friends in town, they seem to flake out a lot.

terminalCity.speaker: artemis
terminalCity.line: Like, on my last birthday, I decided to throw a get together party-like thing, and a bunch of people RSVPed, but all but two of them flaked out at the last minute.

terminalCity.speaker: artemis
terminalCity.line: And the ones who did show up were like 2 hours late.

terminalCity.speaker: zeff
terminalCity.line: Wow, that's too bad. I guess cities can be pretty alienating, huh?

terminalCity.speaker: artemis
terminalCity.line: Vent in agreement about the alienating nature of this city

terminalCity.speaker: artemis
terminalCity.line: Wonder if maybe it's just your fault for being boring

terminalCity-condos.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-condos.line: Yeah. Feels like there are too many condos and not enough community. Plus, everything's expensive, so no one can really afford to go out a lot.

terminalCity-condos.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-condos.line: To make it worse, there's barely any reason to go out. A real city would have more nightlife; everything around here closes at like 11 PM.

terminalCity-condos.speaker: zeff
terminalCity-condos.line: It must be better than living out in the boonies, at least. I feel so isolated from everything. I don't even have enough friends I could invite to a party, except if it were held in Epic Fantasy Online.

terminalCity-condos.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-condos.line: I have to admit, sometimes I wonder about going off to live somewhere more secluded, where I don't have to pay as much rent and can sit around and make art all day.

terminalCity-condos.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-condos.line: It's a someday maybe thing, though. Right now, I like being able to bike commute everywhere and have a grocery store within walking distance of my apartment.

terminalCity-condos.speaker: zeff
terminalCity-condos.line: I think I'd just settle for living somewhere where I knew more people close to my age who had the same geeky interests as me, so that I wouldn't have to travel so far to see friends.

terminalCity-condos.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-condos.line: Wonder if maybe it's just your fault for being boring

terminalCity-boring.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-boring.line: Of course, it could also be my fault. I'm not great at throwing parties. Maybe I project some kind of aura of this is probably going to be boring and not worth your time. Maybe I'm just not a very exciting person.

terminalCity-boring.speaker: zeff
terminalCity-boring.line: I don't think you're boring at all! If you invited me to a party, I'd probably go. If I weren't six hours away, that is.

terminalCity-boring.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-boring.line: Say it's nice of #zeffObj# to say that

terminalCity-boring.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-boring.line: Say you weren't fishing for compliments

terminalCity-thanks.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-thanks.line: Thanks. That's nice of you to say.

terminalCity-fishing.speaker: artemis
terminalCity-fishing.line: Oh, I wasn't fishing for compliments. I made peace with my relatively antisocial nature a long time ago.

diversity.speaker: artemis
diversity.line: You know, is it just me, or is AwesomeCon an overwhelmingly white convention? Besides myself, I think I could count the other people of colour I saw on one hand.

diversity.speaker: zeff
diversity.line: Hmm. I actually didn't notice that, but now that you mention it, you're right. There isn't a lot of ethnic diversity here at all.

diversity.speaker: artemis
diversity.line: Say of course #zeffSub# didn't notice, being white

diversity.speaker: artemis
diversity.line: Point out that the city in general is a lot more diverse

diversity-ofCourse.speaker: artemis
diversity-ofCourse.line: Of course you didn't notice. You're white. Hell, it sometimes takes ME a while to notice, because I'm so used to everyone around me being white like it's a completely normal thing. Even though I'm clearly not.

diversity-ofCourse.speaker: artemis
diversity-ofCourse.line: Talk about how people always ask you where you're from

diversity-weird.speaker: artemis
diversity-weird.line: It's weird to me, because the city in general actually is a lot more diverse. You'd think that AwesomeCon would reflect this somewhat, but no, it's complete, utter Whitesville on that expo floor.

diversity-weird.speaker: artemis
diversity-weird.line: Talk about how people always ask you where you're from

diversity-whereYouFrom.speaker: artemis
diversity-whereYouFrom.line: Anyway, I can't even count the number of times people come up to my table, ask me where I'm from, and when I tell them, are like, no really, where are you from?

diversity-whereYouFrom.speaker: zeff
diversity-whereYouFrom.line: Say that sometimes people ask where you're from because of your unusual name

diversity-whereYouFrom.speaker: zeff
diversity-whereYouFrom.line: Dare to ask where Artemis is from

diversity-whereYouFrom.speaker: artemis
diversity-whereYouFrom.line: Wonder why people just don't believe you've lived in Cascadia your entire life

diversity-annoying.speaker: artemis
diversity-annoying.line: Wonder why people just don't believe you've lived in Cascadia your entire life

diversity-meToo.speaker: zeff
diversity-meToo.line: Sometimes, people ask me where I'm from because of my unusual name. But I guess that's not the same, is it?

diversity-meToo.speaker: artemis
diversity-meToo.line: Wonder why people just don't believe you've lived in Cascadia your entire life

diversity-dareIAsk.speaker: zeff
diversity-dareIAsk.line: Wait, I don't think you actually told me where you're from. Dare I ask?

diversity-dareIAsk.speaker: artemis
diversity-dareIAsk.line: Say you come from your mother's uterus

diversity-dareIAsk.speaker: artemis
diversity-dareIAsk.line: Say you figure what he's really asking is where your parents are from

diversity-lol.speaker: artemis
diversity-lol.line: Wonder why people just don't believe you've lived in Cascadia your entire life

diversity-okay.speaker: zeff
diversity-okay.line: Okay, maybe I shouldn't have asked.

diversity-okay.speaker: artemis
diversity-okay.line: Wonder why people just don't believe you've lived in Cascadia your entire life

diversity-parents.speaker: artemis
diversity-parents.line: Oh, I'm from here. But I'm guessing what you're really asking is where my parents are from.

diversity-parents.speaker: artemis
diversity-parents.line: Tell Zeff about where your parents are from

diversity-parents.speaker: artemis
diversity-parents.line: Wonder why people just don't believe you've lived in Cascadia your entire life

diversity-entireLife.speaker: artemis
diversity-entireLife.line: I mean, I tell them I was born in Douglas, moved to St. Helens when I was six, then moved to the greater Terminal City area during high school. What more do they want?

diversity-entireLife.speaker: artemis
diversity-entireLife.line: Can they just not believe I've lived in Cascadia my entire life just because my melanin levels are more concentrated than theirs? Seriously.

diversity-entireLife.speaker: zeff
diversity-entireLife.line: Say you see Artemis not as a person of colour, but a person

diversity-entireLife.speaker: zeff
diversity-entireLife.line: Point out that we're a nation of immigrants

diversity-entireLife.speaker: zeff
diversity-entireLife.line: Suggest that Artemis claim to be from outer space

diversity-immigrants.speaker: zeff
diversity-immigrants.line: I don't know that people really mean anything bad by it. We're a nation of immigrants. My great-grandparents came from Scotland and Ireland, and I have a bit of Native blood in me, too.

diversity-immigrants.speaker: artemis
diversity-immigrants.line: Yeah, but do people come up to you and ask you about that on a regular basis?

diversity-immigrants.speaker: zeff
diversity-immigrants.line: Uh... no. No, they don't. Wow, that was insensitive of me.

diversity-immigrants.speaker: artemis
diversity-immigrants.line: Talk about people coming up and speaking to you in Spanish

diversity-space.speaker: zeff
diversity-space.line: Maybe you should tell them you're from outer space? That might shut them up.

diversity-space.speaker: artemis
diversity-space.line: I'll be lying if I said the thought didn't occur to me. Sometimes I also think about pretending I'm a time traveller from the future, where everyone's so interbred that race doesn't exist anymore.

diversity-space.speaker: zeff
diversity-space.line: Oh, the horror! But how will we oppress people who look different from us?

diversity-space.speaker: artemis
diversity-space.line: Well, we can always continue subjugating women. Unless we also decide that gender no longer exists. Wouldn't that be nice?

diversity-space.speaker: zeff
diversity-space.line: You know, that would be kind of nice! I've always thought gender was pretty pointless.

diversity-space.speaker: artemis
diversity-space.line: Talk about people coming up and speaking to you in Spanish

diversity-spanish.speaker: artemis
diversity-spanish.line: What's also weird is that people around here who look like me always come up to me and start speaking Spanish. I don't even know Spanish, except for basic tourist stuff like asking where to find el baño.

diversity-spanish.speaker: zeff
diversity-spanish.line: Maybe you should learn some Spanish to mess with their heads.

diversity-spanish.speaker: artemis
diversity-spanish.line: I've thought about it, and I just don't have time to pick up more languages. I mean, I barely feel like I'm good enough at English as it is.

diversity-spanish.speaker: zeff
diversity-spanish.line: Protest that Artemis speaks English just fine

diversity-spanish.speaker: zeff
diversity-spanish.line: Say that you think learning new languages is fun

diversity-spanish.speaker: zeff
diversity-spanish.line: Talk about European gamer friends you know who speak like a million languages

diversity-english.speaker: zeff
diversity-english.line: But you speak English just fine.

diversity-english.speaker: artemis
diversity-english.line: I mean as a writer. There's so much language in there to master, and I feel like I'm barely any of the way there.

diversity-english.speaker: artemis
diversity-english.line: What's more is whenever I've tried picking up another language, I'd feel so uncomfortably limited in self-expression. It's so hard to go through that learning curve. So, I feel like I'd rather stick with the one language I know best.

diversity-english.speaker: zeff
diversity-english.line: Say that you think learning new languages is fun

diversity-english.speaker: zeff
diversity-english.line: Talk about European gamer friends you know who speak like a million languages

diversity-languages.speaker: zeff
diversity-languages.line: I think learning new languages is fun. I took a couple of Japanese classes in college. I was pretty bad at it, but I really liked learning about how different the vocabulary is from English, and how it changes the way people think.

diversity-european.speaker: zeff
diversity-european.line: Yeah, I can see that. I'm always really intimidated when I'm playing games with folks from Germany or France or Sweden, and it turns out that not only can they speak English better than me, they also speak like four or five other languages just as well.

diversity-european.speaker: artemis
diversity-european.line: Tell me about it. Now I feel so uncultured.

criticism.speaker: artemis
criticism.line: You know what's really bizarre about being a webcomic artist who isn't a straight white guy? You don't just get criticism; you get annoying people constantly trying to help you.

criticism.speaker: artemis
criticism.line: Like, random dudes -- and 99% of the time, it's a dude -- say they love my comic and then offer to help with my drawing. By giving me art tips, or offering to draw the comic for me.

criticism.speaker: artemis
criticism.line: Or, sometimes, they do the same with my writing... they'll give me so-called helpful pointers, or rewrite entire strips to make the dialogue more punchy or whatever.

criticism.speaker: zeff
criticism.line: Say it sounds better than being told your stuff sucks

criticism.speaker: zeff
criticism.line: Wonder if they're doing it because they like Artemis

criticism.speaker: zeff
criticism.line: Say the same thing happened when you released your music under a female pseudonym

criticism-better.speaker: zeff
criticism-better.line: Well, that's, uh, nice of them, I guess. Better than being all like, your comic sucks! Goodness knows I get enough of that with my music.

criticism-better.speaker: artemis
criticism-better.line: See, the thing is, it would be nice if I actually asked for feedback. But this just comes out of nowhere!

criticism-better.speaker: artemis
criticism-better.line: It's like, by trying to help me when I don't ask for it, what they're saying is that I need help, and am therefore not good at what I do.

criticism-better.speaker: zeff
criticism-better.line: Ask why they would help you if they didn't want you to get better

criticism-better.speaker: zeff
criticism-better.line: Wonder if they're doing it because they like Artemis

criticism-better.speaker: artemis
criticism-better.line: Wonder if it means you really aren't good enough

criticism-cynicism.speaker: zeff
criticism-cynicism.line: But if they're helping you, doesn't that mean they want you to get better?

criticism-cynicism.speaker: artemis
criticism-cynicism.line: That's the thing. Maybe they want me to get better, but so long as they're the ones giving me the advice, they still get to posture themselves as the more talented, knowledgeable person in the exchange.

criticism-cynicism.speaker: zeff
criticism-cynicism.line: Wonder if they're doing it because they like Artemis

criticism-cynicism.speaker: artemis
criticism-cynicism.line: Wonder if it means you really aren't good enough

criticism-like.speaker: zeff
criticism-like.line: Maybe they're doing it because they like you? Sometimes, people show they like other people by helping them.

criticism-like.speaker: artemis
criticism-like.line: I don't get that. If you like people, why don't you respect them as equals? Why do you have to constantly prove that you know more than they do?

criticism-like.speaker: artemis
criticism-like.line: I don't try to help people I like unless they ask for it. That's how it should be.

criticism-like.speaker: zeff
criticism-like.line: Say it's more of a thing that guys do

criticism-guys.speaker: zeff
criticism-guys.line: I think it's more of a thing that guys do. I mean, it makes sense; we're socialised to want to protect women and all.

criticism-guys.speaker: artemis
criticism-guys.line: Yeah, well, I'm not a damsel in distress, and any guy who can't realise that is, quite frankly, a stereotyping dumbass.

criticism-pseudonym.speaker: zeff
criticism-pseudonym.line: You know, the same thing happened to me when I wrote some music and released it under a female pseudonym.

criticism-pseudonym.speaker: zeff
criticism-pseudonym.line: Suddenly, instead of being all like YOUR MUSIC SUCKS, people suddenly got nicer and started giving me constructive criticism.

criticism-pseudonym.speaker: artemis
criticism-pseudonym.line: Oh yeah. And how did that make you feel?

criticism-pseudonym.speaker: zeff
criticism-pseudonym.line: I don't know. Good, mostly. I mean, I know my music needs to improve, so it's good to have people offering to help. But I felt weird that they were only doing it because they thought I was a girl.

criticism-pseudonym.speaker: artemis
criticism-pseudonym.line: Say that said weirdness never goes away

criticism-pseudonym.speaker: artemis
criticism-pseudonym.line: Express surprise that some people like getting unsolicited advice

criticism-weirdness.speaker: artemis
criticism-weirdness.line: I'm sad to say that said weirdness doesn't really go away. Or maybe that's just me. Maybe women are just supposed to get used to it and I'm defective. I don't know.

criticism-surprise.speaker: artemis
criticism-surprise.line: Huh. I guess some people like getting unsolicited advice. I feel like it expresses a lack of respect, so I'm uncomfortable with it.

criticism-surprise.speaker: zeff
criticism-surprise.line: Well, when it's between being told your stuff is crap and being told how you can improve it, I'd much rather be told how I can improve it.

ideas.speaker: artemis
ideas.line: You know, what if it's true and I'm really not good enough to make webcomics? I think about that all the time.

ideas.speaker: artemis
ideas.line: Like, sometimes, I worry that one day, I'm going to completely run out of ideas. And that scares me. I'm not sure what I'd do with myself if that happened.

ideas.speaker: zeff
ideas.line: Ask if it's even possible to run out of ideas

ideas.speaker: zeff
ideas.line: Ask what it even means to run out of ideas, anyway

ideas.speaker: artemis
ideas.line: Say you're also worried that none of your ideas are original

ideas-possible.speaker: zeff
ideas-possible.line: Is it even possible to run out of ideas?

ideas-possible.speaker: artemis
ideas-possible.line: I don't know. Maybe it isn't. But then again, maybe it is. And that kind of scares me.

ideas-possible.speaker: artemis
ideas-possible.line: Say you're also worried that none of your ideas are original

ideas-meaning.speaker: zeff
ideas-meaning.line: What does it even mean to run out of ideas, anyway?

ideas-meaning.speaker: artemis
ideas-meaning.line: I was thinking along the lines of, what if I couldn't come up with stories to write for my webcomic anymore? Or with any new creative projects after that? What if my inspiration just completely dried up?

ideas-meaning.speaker: zeff
ideas-meaning.line: Ah. I don't really think I'm afraid of running out of ideas for making music. There are just so many sounds to be heard and thoughts to express with them, I think.

ideas-meaning.speaker: artemis
ideas-meaning.line: Say you're also worried that none of your ideas are original

ideas-original.speaker: artemis
ideas-original.line: I'm also worried that none of my ideas are original. That they've all been done before, and better than I ever could, and there's no point in me putting my work out there.

ideas-original.speaker: zeff
ideas-original.line: Talk about how originality requires practice

ideas-original.speaker: zeff
ideas-original.line: Wonder if all of human history has happened before

ideas-encouraging.speaker: zeff
ideas-encouraging.line: Oh, come on, don't say that! Your stuff's awesome! Who cares if it's completely original or whatever that means? What matters is that it's something you made, and there is only one of you in the world.

ideas-encouraging.speaker: artemis
ideas-encouraging.line: Say that's nice of #zeffObj# to say

ideas-encouraging.speaker: artemis
ideas-encouraging.line: Wonder if maybe there are duplicates of you everywhere

ideas-nice.speaker: artemis
ideas-nice.line: That's... nice of you to say.

ideas-duplicates.speaker: artemis
ideas-duplicates.line: Yeah, but is there really? Maybe there are in fact duplicates of me everywhere, of whom I'm completely unaware.

ideas-duplicates.speaker: artemis
ideas-duplicates.line: Maybe I'm nothing more than a data file, executing the same set of instructions over and over again.

ideas-duplicates.speaker: zeff
ideas-duplicates.line: Maybe we all are. So what? I still happen to think you're really talented.

ideas-practice.speaker: zeff
ideas-practice.line: Well, it's been said that with every art form, the first ten thousand hours you spend on it will result in mostly mediocre crap. To be truly brilliant and original, you have to keep at it for long time. Then you can break through.

ideas-practice.speaker: zeff
ideas-practice.line: So, all that is to say is, keep at it.

ideas-practice.speaker: artemis
ideas-practice.line: Say what if you died before you got that far

ideas-practice.speaker: artemis
ideas-practice.line: Say some people just have a lot of natural talent

ideas-died.speaker: artemis
ideas-died.line: Yeah, well, what if I never get there in time? What if, say, I die before I get that far? Won't that make it all pointless?

ideas-died.speaker: zeff
ideas-died.line: No, of course not. You'll still be a person, and most people don't have ten thousand hours of practice doing anything, and I'd be very hard pressed to say their lives are all pointless.

ideas-died.speaker: zeff
ideas-died.line: It's one thing to be down on yourself, but being down on everyone else takes a special kind of misanthropy.

ideas-died.speaker: artemis
ideas-died.line: Say that maybe you do hate everyone

ideas-died.speaker: artemis
ideas-died.line: Say you lack non-artistic redeeming qualities, unlike most people

ideas-hate.speaker: artemis
ideas-hate.line: Well, maybe I do hate everyone. So there.

ideas-hate.speaker: zeff
ideas-hate.line: If that's really the case, you're being awfully nice about it.

ideas-hate.speaker: artemis
ideas-hate.line: Say you lack non-artistic redeeming qualities, unlike most people

ideas-redeeming.speaker: artemis
ideas-redeeming.line: But the thing is, I don't think I have any other redeeming qualities, other than making art and writing. I'm not like a super charismatic person everyone loves or anything like that.

ideas-redeeming.speaker: artemis
ideas-redeeming.line: I haven't invented anything useful, either, or made any scientific discoveries. So, I'm hard pressed to think of any other possible ways I could contribute to society.

ideas-redeeming.speaker: zeff
ideas-redeeming.line: Well, I happen to think you're pretty awesome, and I'm really glad I'm having this conversation right here with you. I don't know if that counts for anything, but there you have it.

ideas-talent.speaker: artemis
ideas-talent.line: What about people who seem to just be born really, really talented? Like prodigies? People even younger than me? I have a hard time believing they've had any more time than I've had...

ideas-talent.speaker: zeff
ideas-talent.line: Suggest that maybe they secretly have time travel talent

ideas-talent.speaker: zeff
ideas-talent.line: Suggest that family plays a part in it too

ideas-timeTravel.speaker: zeff
ideas-timeTravel.line: Could be that they also have secret time travel talent, maybe?

ideas-timeTravel.speaker: artemis
ideas-timeTravel.line: Yeah, and secret anti-aging talent, too. Though I shouldn't be one to talk; judging by my genetics, I'm going to look eighteen years old until I'm forty.

ideas-family.speaker: zeff
ideas-family.line: Ah, but there's also whatever your family pushes you to do in your early formative years.

ideas-family.speaker: zeff
ideas-family.line: Take Mozart, for example. If that movie from the eighties is any indication, he came out a brilliant genius, but didn't he also come from a family of musicians?

ideas-family.speaker: zeff
ideas-family.line: And when you learn to do things as a little kid, it's practically second nature to the point that it looks natural. That's why it's easier to teach, say, new languages to a toddler. I guess the same would apply to art and music.

ideas-family.speaker: artemis
ideas-family.line: Okay, but does this mean that if I didn't learn to be a webcomic artist in the womb or whatever, there's no point in me starting later?

ideas-family.speaker: zeff
ideas-family.line: No, it just means you get a later start. It's not a race! And as far as I'm concerned, you're doing fine.

ideas-family.speaker: artemis
ideas-family.line: Argue that sometimes it feels like a race

ideas-race.speaker: artemis
ideas-race.line: Sometimes it feels like a race, though. It's all about who had the ideas first, it seems. Everyone else... well, people stop caring after they've seen it before.

ideas-race.speaker: zeff
ideas-race.line: Well, that's a really cynical way of looking at one's audience.

ideas-history.speaker: zeff
ideas-history.line: Well, there are speculations that this entire time and place we're living in now has happened before, and so has all of human history.

ideas-history.speaker: zeff
ideas-history.line: And that we're constantly forgetting what happened before, because all our memories have been erased and so has the bulk of human history, so we have to keep on reliving everything over and over.

ideas-reincarnation.speaker: artemis
ideas-reincarnation.line: You mean like a reincarnation kind of concept?

artemisParents.speaker: artemis
artemisParents.line: They grew up in the Philippines. They came here before I was born, though, so I've lived here my entire life.

artemisParents.speaker: artemis
artemisParents.line: It feels like my relationship with my folks is all about annoying culture clashes.

artemisParents.speaker: zeff
artemisParents.line: Ask what sorts of culture clashes

artemisParents.speaker: artemis
artemisParents.line: Voice some of your worries about denying your cultural heritage

artemisParents-clashes.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-clashes.line: Talk about how it was hard to move out of their house

artemisParents-clashes.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-clashes.line: Talk about how they're not okay with you being queer

artemisParents-independent.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-independent.line: Well, for starters, they come from a place and time where you basically lived with your parents until you got married and probably even after, raising your own family under the same roof.

artemisParents-independent.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-independent.line: When I wanted to move out for college and be independent, they couldn't understand why.

artemisParents-independent.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-independent.line: Point out that most of the world can't even afford independence

artemisParents-independent.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-independent.line: Say you can relate to wanting to be away from family

artemisParents-independent.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-independent.line: Say it's annoying that your little brother still lives at home

artemisParents-independent.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-independent.line: Voice some of your worries about denying your cultural heritage

artemisParents-afford.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-afford.line: I can see their point. Independence is largely a Western ideal, isn't it? And most of the world can't even afford to live alone, so it's no wonder it's unheard of in a lot of cultures.

artemisParents-afford.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-afford.line: Yeah, but I wonder how many people in those cultures would live independently if they had the chance. My family is pretty extroverted, and I feel like the odd one out because I need to have peace and quiet.

artemisParents-afford.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-afford.line: I know for a fact that I have a way better relationship with them if we don't have to live together or see each other every day.

artemisParents-afford.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-afford.line: Then again, maybe I just wouldn't know better. I don't know.

artemisParents-afford.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-afford.line: Say it's wasteful that rich people have so much space all for themselves

artemisParents-afford.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-afford.line: Say you can relate to wanting to be away from family

artemisParents-afford.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-afford.line: Say it's annoying that your little brother still lives at home

artemisParents-afford.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-afford.line: Voice some of your worries about denying your cultural heritage

artemisParents-wasteful.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-wasteful.line: I feel like it's also kind of wasteful that rich people can afford such huge spaces just for themselves. Not just their houses, but their cars, too. Especially with overpopulation and overcrowding everywhere else.

artemisParents-wasteful.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-wasteful.line: You're probably right. And I don't think it's that I want a lot of space, or to live any kind of an extravagant lifestyle. I just want a space that's all mine. It can be a closet, for all I care.

artemisParents-wasteful.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-wasteful.line: Say it's annoying that your little brother still lives at home

artemisParents-wasteful.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-wasteful.line: Voice some of your worries about denying your cultural heritage

artemisParents-brother.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-brother.line: The most annoying part is, my little brother still lives at home, and they keep heaping favouritism on him because of it. Then again, they've always been so much less strict with him because he's a boy.

artemisParents-brother.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-brother.line: Ask if Zeff has any siblings

artemisParents-brother.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-brother.line: Voice some of your worries about denying your cultural heritage

artemisParents-queer.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-queer.line: The queer thing is a big one. They keep freaking out and asking me if I'm a lesbian. I've tried explaining bisexuality to them, but they don't understand it. They're always like, if you like men, why don't you just date men?

artemisParents-queer.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-queer.line: Point out that sometimes that is in fact what people do

artemisParents-queer.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-queer.line: Compare the situation to interracial dating

artemisParents-biInvisibility.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-biInvisibility.line: Sometimes, that is in fact what people do: just date people of the socially sanctioned gender, because it's the easiest way out. It's the whole bisexual invisibility thing.

artemisParents-biInvisibility.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-biInvisibility.line: Compare the situation to interracial dating

artemisParents-biInvisibility.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-biInvisibility.line: Voice some of your worries about denying your cultural heritage

artemisParents-suck.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-suck.line: Compare the situation to interracial dating

artemisParents-suck.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-suck.line: Voice some of your worries about denying your cultural heritage

artemisParents-interracial.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-interracial.line: It doesn't make any sense to me, though! It's like saying, if you like white people, why don't you just date white people? It's awful! People are people.

artemisParents-interracial.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-interracial.line: Granted, interracial dating is still an issue for some people, but at least most of civilised society recognises it for the racist bullshit it is.

artemisParents-interracial.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-interracial.line: Voice some of your worries about denying your cultural heritage

artemisParents-heritage.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-heritage.line: The thing is, sometimes, by breaking away from my parents' traditional values, I worry that I'm denying my cultural heritage. And I feel it's important to honour where we came from.

artemisParents-heritage.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-heritage.line: Sometimes, my family makes comments to me about being white on the inside, which I hate. I mean, I'm not white, which is obvious to anyone looking at me. I don't get to have white privilege.

artemisParents-heritage.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-heritage.line: But at the same time, I don't really feel like I get to be Filipino either.

artemisParents-heritage.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-heritage.line: Sympathetically say that must be rough

artemisParents-heritage.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-heritage.line: Point out that whiteness isn't an obvious concept

artemisParents-rough.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-rough.line: That must be rough. I can't even imagine what it would feel like not to belong. Well, actually, I can, but not like this. So... yeah. I'm sorry.

artemisParents-rough.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-rough.line: Ah, it's nothing to apologise about. It's just life. At least it is for me. I'm used to being the odd one out everywhere I go.

artemisParents-whiteness.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-whiteness.line: I don't know that whiteness is such an obvious concept. It used to be that Jewish and Irish folks were considered non-white.

artemisParents-whiteness.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-whiteness.line: Yeah, well, I'm pretty clearly on the person of colour side of that grey area, and I feel it.

artemisParents-whiteness.speaker: artemis
artemisParents-whiteness.line: It's not fun when you're in kindergarten and someone asks you why you pronounce words funny because you learned them from your mom and dad. Or when you bring food to school and everyone complains that it stinks.

artemisParents-whiteness.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-whiteness.line: Sympathetically say that must be rough

artemisParents-whiteness.speaker: zeff
artemisParents-whiteness.line: Say you see Artemis not as a person of colour, but a person

zeffParents.speaker: zeff
zeffParents.line: I can relate to wanting to be away from family. I'm living with my mom at the moment. I love her, but sometimes she can be a bit too much to take on a regular basis.

zeffParents.speaker: zeff
zeffParents.line: That said, as far as roommate situations, it's not the worst I've ever been in. It's just been us two for most of my life, anyway, so it's comfortable.

zeffParents.speaker: artemis
zeffParents.line: Say it's good that they get along

zeffParents.speaker: zeff
zeffParents.line: Talk about how you never knew your dad growing up

zeffParents-getAlong.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-getAlong.line: It's good that you get along. I mean, whatever works, right?

zeffParents-getAlong.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-getAlong.line: Yeah. It's nice that I actually have some time to work on my music. I mean, I know people who have to be working almost 16 hours a day to be able to afford to live. The housing market is pretty ridiculous nowadays.

zeffParents-getAlong.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-getAlong.line: Talk about how you never knew your dad growing up

zeffParents-siblings.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-siblings.line: Nope. Not that I know of, anyway.

zeffParents-siblings.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-siblings.line: It's possible that the Neanderthal who sired me probably went on to sow his wild oats and produce biologically related siblings who for all I know could be anywhere in the world, but as far as real family is concerned, it's just me and my mom.

zeffParents-siblings.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-siblings.line: Talk about how you never knew your dad growing up

zeffParents-dad.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-dad.line: I never knew my dad growing up. I wasn't ever really that curious. I figured that if he was out of me and my mom's life, then he wasn't really a person worth knowing.

zeffParents-dad.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-dad.line: That's a healthy way of looking at it. Of course, I grew up with my parents still together the whole time, so I can't really know what it's like, so to speak.

zeffParents-dad.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-dad.line: Talk about when your dad randomly showed up at your house when you were 14

zeffParents-dad.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-dad.line: Rant about the idea of traditional marriage and its supposed superiority

zeffParents-showedUp.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-showedUp.line: Oh, but one time, when I was like 14 or thereabouts, suddenly, this guy shows up at our house saying he's my dad and he wants to get to know me. I was really weirded out.

zeffParents-showedUp.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-showedUp.line: Ask what #zeffDet# mom had to say about that

zeffParents-showedUp.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-showedUp.line: Say you can imagine that must have been weird

zeffParents-showedUp.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-showedUp.line: Talk about how you learned you had nothing in common with your dad

zeffParents-mom.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-mom.line: What did your mom have to say about that?

zeffParents-mom.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-mom.line: She was mostly neutral. She'd long since forgiven him for leaving, or at least, stopped caring enough to be civil with him as an acquaintance. And she figured it might be good for me to know who my dad was, I guess.

zeffParents-mom.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-mom.line: Talk about how you learned you had nothing in common with your dad

zeffParents-imagine.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-imagine.line: Talk about how you learned you had nothing in common with your dad

zeffParents-nothing.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-nothing.line: Anyway, he takes me out to a football game and talks about hunting and beer and all these laughably stereotypical manly things, and I remember just see the increasing disappointment in his eyes as it dawned on him that we had absolutely nothing in common.

zeffParents-nothing.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-nothing.line: He dropped me off at home, and I swear he muttered something along the lines of pathetic little faggot when he thought I couldn't hear him. I never heard or saw from him again.

zeffParents-nothing.description: Told a story about your deadbeat dad

zeffParents-nothing.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-nothing.line: Express your disgust for Zeff's father

zeffParents-nothing.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-nothing.line: Rant about the idea of traditional marriage and its supposed superiority

zeffParents-asswipe.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-asswipe.line: That's disgusting. What an asswipe. Who would say that to their own child? Seriously.

zeffParents-asswipe.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-asswipe.line: Eh, I guess it helps that I'm not his child, and he was nothing to me but a sperm donor. I mean, the way I see it, I'm glad I didn't have to spend my childhood being raised by a guy like him. I feel like I dodged a bullet.

zeffParents-asswipe.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-asswipe.line: Rant about the idea of traditional marriage and its supposed superiority

zeffParents-twoParent.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-twoParent.line: You know, I've always thought it was bullshit how all those conservative family values people always stress the importance of having two-parent households and preserving heterosexual marriage and all that.

zeffParents-twoParent.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-twoParent.line: They conveniently forget that it's better for kids to have one parent who's a decent human being than two parents where at least one is an abusive shithead.

zeffParents-twoParent.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-twoParent.line: Mind you, two parents who are decent human beings aren't necessarily perfect and non-dysfunctional, either, and I speak from experience.

zeffParents-twoParent.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-twoParent.line: Talk about the kid you know who has three parents

zeffParents-polyamory.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-polyamory.line: I know a kid who has three parents, all of whom are decent human beings. She's probably got the best deal of the lot. Having more adults around makes things easier, I guess. At least that's what the parents say.

zeffParents-polyamory.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-polyamory.line: Not that there isn't dysfunction in polyamorous relationships too, but you know. They seem generally happy

zeffParents-tolstoy.speaker: artemis
zeffParents-tolstoy.line: Was it Tolstoy who said that thing about how all dysfunctional families are dysfunctional in their own way?

zeffParents-tolstoy.speaker: zeff
zeffParents-tolstoy.line: I think he was talking about unhappy families, but I guess the same thing applies. I don't know. I haven't actually read the book.

dontSeeColour.speaker: zeff
dontSeeColour.line: This may sound a bit daft, but I don't see you as a person of colour. I see you as a person.

dontSeeColour.speaker: artemis
dontSeeColour.line: That's... that's well-meaning of you, but it feels like I'm trying to explain my experience and you're trying to erase it.

dontSeeColour.speaker: artemis
dontSeeColour.line: I've heard the I don't see colour argument from white people before, and it's never helped before, and it isn't helping now. So I'd appreciate it if you stopped, okay?

dontSeeColour-stop.speaker: zeff
dontSeeColour-stop.line: Okay, I'll stop. Sorry. That was a really ignorant thing to say.

dontSeeColour-explain.speaker: zeff
dontSeeColour-explain.line: Well, what I really meant is that I believe in treating everyone equally, and I see you as... you know what, forget it. Clearly, I suck at explaining myself.

religion.speaker: artemis
religion.line: The thing is, I'm kinda allergic to the supernatural, and ideas about life after death and God and such.

religion.speaker: artemis
religion.line: I was raised pretty religious, but after it became clear to me that being queer and not a feminine stereotype wasn't going to fly in the church in which I was raised... yeah, not so much.

religion.speaker: artemis
religion.line: But even before that, I never really felt the presence of any kind of god figure in my life, like other religious people said they did. I never felt anything when, say, praying or anything like that.

religion.speaker: zeff
religion.line: Talk about how your mom was really into hippie new age spirituality

religion.speaker: artemis
religion.line: Talk about the conversation you had with your super religious aunt recently

religion.speaker: artemis
religion.line: Ask if Zeff believes in some kind of God

religion-mom.speaker: zeff
religion-mom.line: My mom was always into a lot of hippie new agey spirituality. She'd get really into a new belief system every year or so -- Buddhism, Taoism, Sufism, Christian mysticism, you name it.

religion-mom.speaker: artemis
religion-mom.line: Ask if Zeff believes in some kind of God

religion-mom.speaker: artemis
religion-mom.line: Talk about the conversation you had with your super religious aunt recently

religion-god.speaker: artemis
religion-god.line: What about you? Do you believe in some kind of God-like figure?

religion-god.speaker: zeff
religion-god.line: Hmm. Yes and no. It's complicated.

religion-god.speaker: zeff
religion-god.line: I think it depends on whoever's doing the believing. If you believe in the Judeo-Christian God, he exists. If you believe in the Flying Spaghetti Monster or Zeus, then they exist. If you believe in nothing, then nothing exists. I think it's in the eye of the beholder.

religion-god.speaker: artemis
religion-god.line: Suggest Zeff believes in the placebo effect

religion-placebo.speaker: artemis
religion-placebo.line: So you're saying you believe in the placebo effect.

religion-placebo.speaker: zeff
religion-placebo.line: That's exactly what it is, yeah.

religion-personally.speaker: artemis
religion-personally.line: Okay... but what do you personally believe?

religion-personally.speaker: zeff
religion-personally.line: See, I don't know. Sometimes, I like to believe there's some kind of higher power or mystical force that makes everything make sense somehow. But sometimes, I feel like it's all just random nonsense.

religion-personally.speaker: artemis
religion-personally.line: So, you believe in some sort of Schroedinger's Cat god.

religion-personally.speaker: zeff
religion-personally.line: Yeah, I guess you could say that.

religion-personally.speaker: artemis
religion-personally.line: Talk about the conversation you had with your super religious aunt recently

religion-aunt.speaker: artemis
religion-aunt.line: I was talking to my super religious aunt about the story of Adam and Eve the other week. And it got me thinking about how I can't really relate to the message people seem to get from it.

religion-aunt.speaker: zeff
religion-aunt.line: You mean like the whole idea of original sin?

religion-aunt.speaker: artemis
religion-aunt.line: To put it in broader terms, the idea that curiosity and knowledge are evil, and that you're better off being ignorant as long as it means you can be safe.

religion-aunt.speaker: artemis
religion-aunt.line: I've never been in any kind of a situation where I'd rather not have known. Even if whatever it was I knew was terrible. To me, it's still better than not knowing.

religion-aunt.speaker: zeff
religion-aunt.line: Say you're not entirely sure if you would agree

religion-notSure.speaker: zeff
religion-notSure.line: I'm not entirely sure about that. Sometimes, I wonder if I really would be happier if I grew up in a simpler era, when my life and my path were all laid out for me.

religion-notSure.speaker: zeff
religion-notSure.line: Maybe I'd live in a tiny community where I knew everyone, marry some woman who was chosen for me, pop out a bunch of kids, and not know any better.

religion-notSure.speaker: zeff
religion-notSure.line: It would save me the pain of having to question the point of it all, you know? Probably involve fewer nights in which I cry myself to sleep in frustration. Sometimes, I wonder about that.

religion-notSure.speaker: artemis
religion-notSure.line: Point out that if you lived in a so-called simpler era, you'd definitely be worse off

religion-burned.speaker: artemis
religion-burned.line: The problem with that is, I know damn well that if I grew up in a so-called simpler era, I'd be burned at the stake or worse. Things really weren't great for women at all, let alone women of colour, or women who just couldn't fit the standard ideal of femininity.

religion-burned.speaker: artemis
religion-burned.line: And I've tried fitting in in this world, and it never worked. So I really don't see how it would be any better in another time.

religion-burned.speaker: zeff
religion-burned.line: Maybe you're right. Maybe I wouldn't be happier at all. Maybe it's impossible for me to be completely happy. I don't know.

religion-makesSense.speaker: zeff
religion-makesSense.line: That makes sense, I guess. Don't they say knowledge is power? I mean, power is a mixed blessing, but then again, powerlessness is worse, I think.

religion-makesSense.speaker: artemis
religion-makesSense.line: Yeah. If there were some way of abolishing the concept of power altogether, that would be nice, wouldn't it?

zeffDream.speaker: zeff
zeffDream.line: So, I had this dream last night. I was here at AwesomeCon, only for some reason, it actually looked more like a cross between my old high school and this casino I went to a couple of years ago, and the architecture was kind of hexagonal-shaped.

zeffDream.speaker: artemis
zeffDream.line: Say you have dreams with fuzzy architecture, too

zeffDream.speaker: artemis
zeffDream.line: Say that's actually an apt description of AwesomeCon

zeffDream-architecture.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-architecture.line: Heh. I have these recurring dreams when I wake up in my apartment, only it's not really my apartment; it's got an extra bedroom and concrete floors, and when I come out, I'm in this fancy hotel hallway with gift shops strewn all about.

zeffDream-aptly.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-aptly.line: I guess that's kind of an apt comparison, if one can be made. AwesomeCon is one part high school and one part a giant casino.

zeffDream-cats.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-cats.line: Anyway, I'm trying to find the registration desk, which everyone tells me is one the other side of a giant maze, so I go into this maze and there are these human-sized cats repeating, over and over again: the monkey room is upstairs, the monkey room is upstairs.

zeffDream-cats.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-cats.line: I keep wandering around, and somehow, I wind up next to this fountain, and I realise I'm not wearing any pants. And then my mom walks up to me, hands me a laundry basket full of styrofoam packing peanuts, and says, take this, it will help you on your quest.

zeffDream-cats.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-cats.line: Wonder if this story is actually going anywhere

zeffDream-going.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-going.line: Is this story actually going anywhere?

zeffDream-going.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-going.line: Yeah, I'm getting to that part.

zeffDream-car.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-car.line: So, all of a sudden, I'm in a car, driving. I can't see anything ahead of me; it's all a blur of bright lights.
Stuck in the Middle with You

zeffDream-car.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-car.line: Meanwhile, Sparrow and Robin, my friends I travelled here with, are in the back seat with a guitar, singing Stuck in the Middle with You in perfect harmony.

zeffDream-car.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-car.line: Actually, now that I think about it, there was also a giant tongue monster in the car too, singing along, and no one found this out of the ordinary.

zeffDream-car.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-car.line: Inquire further about the tongue monster

zeffDream-car.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-car.line: Say it doesn't sound like Zeff was paying attention to the road

zeffDream-car.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-car.line: Mention the part of your dream where the tongue monster starts kissing you

zeffDream-car.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-car.line: Finish the story, omitting the kissing part

zeffDream-tongue.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-tongue.line: Tongue monster? Uh, okay, I'm having trouble picturing what that entails, exactly, but it sounds gross.

zeffDream-tongue.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-tongue.line: Well, just picture this giant tongue with smaller tongues coming out of it, and eyes, a nose, and a mouth. Now that I think of it, it was really disturbing.

zeffDream-tongue.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-tongue.line: Mention the part of your dream where the tongue monster starts kissing you

zeffDream-tongue.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-tongue.line: Finish the story, omitting the kissing part

zeffDream-road.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-road.line: Doesn't sound like you were paying attention to the road, there.

zeffDream-road.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-road.line: It was a dream! I ultimately wasn't going anywhere. And anyway, it didn't really take much effort to look; it's like in my dreams, I have the ability for panoramic vision or something, so I don't have turn my head around, ever.

zeffDream-road.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-road.line: Mention the part of your dream where the tongue monster starts kissing you

zeffDream-road.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-road.line: Finish the story, omitting the kissing part

zeffDream-kissing.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-kissing.line: And then, for some reason, the tongue monster and I wind up alone, and it starts kissing me. Like, everywhere. And then I wake up.

zeffDream-kissing.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-kissing.line: Say your dreams are usually way more boring than that

zeffDream-kissing.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-kissing.line: Ask what Zeff thinks #zeffDet# dream means

zeffDream-finish.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-finish.line: And then, uh, I wake up shortly after that.

zeffDream-finish.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-finish.line: Say your dreams are usually way more boring than that

zeffDream-finish.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-finish.line: Ask what Zeff thinks #zeffDet# dream means

zeffDream-boring.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-boring.line: Huh. My dreams are usually so much more boring than that.

zeffDream-boring.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-boring.line: Usually, they're about trying to find a bathroom and discovering that all the toilets are in an open space with no walls, and I don't want to pee when everyone can watch me, even though I really, really have to.

zeffDream-boring.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-boring.line: Or about still being in school and finding out I'm registered for a class that I never noticed I was registered for, and the final exam is in an hour and I'm going to fail. That sort of thing.

zeffDream-boring.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-boring.line: Huh. I don't always remember my dreams, but when I do, they're always these action-packed epics. Usually to do with some game I've been playing, or some book I've been reading.

zeffDream-boring.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-boring.line: Actually, sometimes I've even written music about my dreams, because they were that inspiring.

zeffDream-boring.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-boring.line: I envy that sometimes. I wish my dreams were inspiringly action-packed, but they're super mundane instead. Probably why I write a slice of life webcomic about single-celled organisms instead of something more exciting.

zeffDream-boring.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-boring.line: I gotta say, your art style is pretty surrealist and dreamlike.

zeffDream-boring.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-boring.line: Yeah, but that's more because I can't draw realism to save my life. If I were able to draw what I see, I figure it wouldn't be super exciting.

zeffDream-analysis.speaker: artemis
zeffDream-analysis.line: What do you think your dream means? Sounds to me like it's covered in delicious layers of symbolism.

zeffDream-analysis.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-analysis.line: Say you think it represents your excitement and anxiety over AwesomeCon

zeffDream-analysis.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-analysis.line: Say you thought it would just be an amusing story

zeffDream-anxiety.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-anxiety.line: Well, I think it represents my excitement over going to AwesomeCon, and that excitement sometimes turns into anxiety. Like, it's so big, what if I get lost and make a complete mess of myself?

zeffDream-anxiety.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-anxiety.line: Of course, that's not going to happen, but still. Some part of me wonders about that stuff, particularly when I'm in big social situations.

zeffDream-dunno.speaker: zeff
zeffDream-dunno.line: I didn't really think about what this dream could mean. I just thought it would make for an amusing story to tell you.

mansplaining.speaker: artemis
mansplaining.line: Wait... I know who you are. You were that guy who had that long Twitter conversation with me about how I handled Gidget's mitosis scene in Bacteria Stories.

mansplaining.speaker: zeff
mansplaining.line: Look... I didn't mean to make you mad at me. I just thought you might appreciate it if I pointed out some factual inconsistencies between that scene and how mitosis works in the real world.

mansplaining.speaker: artemis
mansplaining.line: Well, suffice to say, if I really want that information, I have Wikipedia at my disposal. As it stands, Bacteria Stories is a work of fiction.

mansplaining.speaker: zeff
mansplaining.line: Say you were just trying to help

mansplaining-help.speaker: zeff
mansplaining-help.line: I was only trying to help. I mean, there might actually be cell biologists reading your comic, and I don't want you to get embarrassed.

mansplaining-help.speaker: artemis
mansplaining-help.line: Gee, thanks. It's always nice to know I have a gallant young man protecting me from the many hordes of rabid cell biologists.

mansplaining-help.speaker: artemis
mansplaining-help.line: Typical straight white guys, with their splaining. Yeesh.

mansplaining-help.speaker: zeff
mansplaining-help.line: Say you never said you were straight, and you're not even 100% sure that you're male

mansplaining-never.speaker: zeff
mansplaining-never.line: Hey, now! I never said I was straight, and I'm not even 100% sure about... never mind.

mansplaining-assumed.speaker: artemis
mansplaining-assumed.line: Well, I'm sorry I assumed... but still... it's not really cool to automatically assume people are going to want unsolicited advice.

mansplaining-apologise.speaker: zeff
mansplaining-apologise.line: Look. I just want to say, I'm really sorry for pissing you off. I was an ass, and I hope you can forgive me.

mansplaining-apologise.speaker: artemis
mansplaining-apologise.line: Whatever. Just don't do it again, all right?

harassment.speaker: artemis
harassment.line: Look, a friend of mine got harassed by this guy on the show floor earlier this weekend. I've kind of been on my guard ever since.

harassment.speaker: artemis
harassment.line: Well, more on my guard than usual.

harassment-surprise.speaker: zeff
harassment-surprise.line: I'm sad to say that doesn't surprise me.

harassment-whatHappened.speaker: artemis
harassment-whatHappened.line: He literally came up to her and asked if she was married.

harassment-whatHappened.speaker: artemis
harassment-whatHappened.line: When she said no, he was like, do you want to come up to my room for coffee? With the most unsubtle wink conveying that what he meant by coffee was actually sex.

harassment-whatHappened.speaker: artemis
harassment-whatHappened.line: In retrospect, we both found it kind of funny, but still.

harassment-whatHappened.speaker: artemis
harassment-whatHappened.line: Talk about what weirded you out the most

harassment-whatHappened.speaker: zeff
harassment-whatHappened.line: Ask who that creep was, anyway

harassment-weirded.speaker: artemis
harassment-weirded.line: The thing that really weirded me out, though, was that it was as if I wasn't even there. He pretty much looked right through me as if I was invisible.

harassment-weirded.speaker: zeff
harassment-weirded.line: Point out that maybe that's a relief

harassment-weirded.speaker: artemis
harassment-weirded.line: Wonder aloud why the creeper failed to notice you

harassment-relief.speaker: zeff
harassment-relief.line: Wouldn't that be a relief? I mean, at least it wasn't you getting harassed, right?

harassment-relief.speaker: artemis
harassment-relief.line: Wonder aloud why the creeper failed to notice you

harassment-iCanImagine.speaker: zeff
harassment-iCanImagine.line: Yeah. I can imagine that being super weird.

harassment-iCanImagine.speaker: artemis
harassment-iCanImagine.line: Wonder aloud why the creeper failed to notice you

harassment-whyNotMe.speaker: artemis
harassment-whyNotMe.line: I mean, sure, yeah, being harassed is really shitty and I feel awful for my friend.

harassment-whyNotMe.speaker: artemis
harassment-whyNotMe.line: But, like, why not me? Was I not good enough for him?

harassment-whyNotMe.description: Brought up insecurities about your appearance

harassment-whyNotMe.speaker: artemis
harassment-whyNotMe.line: Did I fail to meet some kind of standard of female attractiveness or something? I don't understand!

harassment-whyNotMe.speaker: zeff
harassment-whyNotMe.line: Ask who that creep was, anyway

harassment-knowTheFeeling.speaker: zeff
harassment-knowTheFeeling.line: Yeah, I know the feeling. Kind of.

harassment-knowTheFeeling.speaker: zeff
harassment-knowTheFeeling.line: I wouldn't want to be harassed either, but it'd be nice if people thought I was worth looking at, too.

harassment-knowTheFeeling.speaker: zeff
harassment-knowTheFeeling.line: Ask who that creep was, anyway

harassment-whoCreep.speaker: zeff
harassment-whoCreep.line: Who was that creep, anyway? You know, so the rest of us can name and shame him.

harassment-whoCreep.speaker: artemis
harassment-whoCreep.line: Say you didn't even think to identify him

harassment-noIdea.speaker: artemis
harassment-noIdea.line: Actually, I have no idea who he was. Just some random, nondescript guy wearing a random, nondescript geeky t-shirt.

harassment-noIdea.speaker: artemis
harassment-noIdea.line: Plus, there's always the problem that publicly naming and shaming brings on even more harassment on the part of the namer and shamer. So there's that.

harassment-noIdea.speaker: zeff
harassment-noIdea.line: Ask if you could do it anonymously

harassment-picture.speaker: artemis
harassment-picture.line: You know, I wish one of us had thought to take a picture, but I guess we were too much in shock to really do anything.

harassment-picture.speaker: artemis
harassment-picture.line: Plus, there's always the problem that publicly naming and shaming brings on even more harassment on the part of the namer and shamer. So there's that.

harassment-picture.speaker: zeff
harassment-picture.line: Ask if you could do it anonymously

harassment-anonymously.speaker: zeff
harassment-anonymously.line: Well, couldn't you do it anonymously?

harassment-anonymously.speaker: artemis
harassment-anonymously.line: You could, but fewer people will believe you. It's kind of a double-edged sword.

harassment-whoFriend.speaker: zeff
harassment-whoFriend.line: If you don't mind my asking... who's your friend? Is she someone well-known?

harassment-whoFriend.speaker: artemis
harassment-whoFriend.line: Say you don't understand why that matters

harassment-whoFriend.speaker: artemis
harassment-whoFriend.line: Give #zeffObj# the benefit of the doubt, but be vague

harassment-matters.speaker: artemis
harassment-matters.line: I don't understand why that matters.

harassment-notMe.speaker: artemis
harassment-notMe.line: It's not me, if that's what you're implying.

harassment-doubt.speaker: artemis
harassment-doubt.line: She's another webcomic artist. That's all you really need to know.

toxic.speaker: artemis
toxic.line: You know, the more I think about it, the whole fan convention environment really is a toxic environment for women.

toxic.speaker: artemis
toxic.line: I mean, there are barely any real women there! All I see are scantily-clad booth babes paid to be gawked at by mouth-breathing nerdbros.

toxic.speaker: artemis
toxic.line: Who would actually, willingly, want to dress like that? I mean, seriously?

toxic.speaker: zeff
toxic.line: Point out that some women do make the choice to dress that way

toxic-choice.speaker: zeff
toxic-choice.line: I wouldn't be so quick to judge. Some women like dressing to show some skin. It should be their choice.

toxic-choice.speaker: artemis
toxic-choice.line: Point out that such a choice can't be independent of patriarchy

toxic-choice.speaker: artemis
toxic-choice.line: Say it's a choice you don't understand personally

toxic-independent.speaker: artemis
toxic-independent.line: They do, but how can such a choice be made independent of a patriarchal society that values women, first and foremost, for their looks?

toxic-independent.speaker: artemis
toxic-independent.line: It's human nature to want to please people in your community. So it's only natural that some women like to dress solely to please people.

toxic-patronising.speaker: zeff
toxic-patronising.line: Wow. That's really, really patronising. What makes you so high and mighty that you're above pleasing people, anyway?

toxic-patronising.speaker: artemis
toxic-patronising.line: Call #zeffObj# out on account of being male

toxic-understand.speaker: artemis
toxic-understand.line: Oh, sure, it's a choice. But that doesn't mean I understand it.

toxic-understand.speaker: artemis
toxic-understand.line: I mean, when I've tried to dress that way, I've always felt so... uncomfortable. Exposed.

toxic-understand.speaker: artemis
toxic-understand.line: I'd look at myself in the mirror and see someone who wasn't me at all. It was some alien.

toxic-understand.speaker: artemis
toxic-understand.line: An alien most men would find way hotter than the real me, sure, but still. Not me.

toxic-understand.speaker: zeff
toxic-understand.line: Say maybe it's not for #artemisObj#, but it is for others

toxic-notForYou.speaker: zeff
toxic-notForYou.line: Well, maybe dressing feminine just isn't you. That's okay. But for some women, that is who they are. And you have to respect that.

toxic-notForYou.speaker: artemis
toxic-notForYou.line: Call #zeffObj# out on account of being male

toxic-man.speaker: artemis
toxic-man.line: You're one to talk. You're a dude. Think about that before the next time you splain your face off about things in which you have no lived experience.

toxic-man.speaker: zeff
toxic-man.line: Point out that you're way more complicated than that

toxic-complicated.speaker: zeff
toxic-complicated.line: See, that's just it! You keep assuming I'm just your bog-standard straight white dude, but that's not me at all!

toxic-complicated.speaker: zeff
toxic-complicated.line: I'm... way more complicated than that.

cosplay.speaker: zeff
cosplay.line: So... yesterday, I, uh, cosplayed as Roberta St. Albert from SleuthQuest.

cosplay.speaker: artemis
cosplay.line: Say you're not familiar with the character

cosplay.speaker: artemis
cosplay.line: Wonder why cross-dressing is a big deal

cosplay-who.speaker: artemis
cosplay-who.line: I've never played SleuthQuest. Who's Roberta St. Albert?

cosplay-who.speaker: zeff
cosplay-who.line: Oh, she's the main villain who you spend the entire game searching for, visiting every country in the world in the process.

cosplay-who.speaker: zeff
cosplay-who.line: She's got long, flaming red hair and wears a little black dress, a fedora, and fishnets. You've probably seen her before; she's pretty recognisable and iconic.

cosplay-who.speaker: artemis
cosplay-who.line: Wonder why cross-dressing is a big deal

cosplay-who.speaker: zeff
cosplay-who.line: Explain that it actually wasn't really cross-dressing

cosplay-bigDeal.speaker: artemis
cosplay-bigDeal.line: I don't know, though... it seems to me like lots of people cross-dress at conventions. I had the impression it wasn't a big deal.

cosplay-bigDeal.speaker: zeff
cosplay-bigDeal.line: Explain that it actually wasn't really cross-dressing

cosplay-crossDressing.speaker: zeff
cosplay-crossDressing.line: See, here's the thing. It wasn't really cross-dressing. I... I've been dressing like that, in private, for years.

cosplay-crossDressing.speaker: zeff
cosplay-crossDressing.line: And, uh, when I wear a wig and a dress and heels, it's the only time I really feel like me. If that makes any sense.

cosplay-crossDressing.speaker: artemis
cosplay-crossDressing.line: Say you kind of get it

cosplay-crossDressing.speaker: artemis
cosplay-crossDressing.line: Talk about the time you wore a tie and a blazer

cosplay-kindOf.speaker: artemis
cosplay-kindOf.line: Kind of. I mean, I do hate wearing all those things, even though I'm supposed to love them. I guess it works the other way around too, huh.

cosplay-blazer.speaker: artemis
cosplay-blazer.line: I felt that way the first time I wore a tie and a blazer to a friend's wedding. It was the first time I realised I didn't hate dressing up, at least not completely.

cosplay-blazer.speaker: artemis
cosplay-blazer.line: I guess it also works the other way around, doesn't it?

cosplay-yesterday.speaker: zeff
cosplay-yesterday.line: Anyway. Yesterday was the first time I did that out in public. And it was amazing. No one recognised me, and a few people even said my cosplay was super accurate.

cosplay-yesterday.speaker: zeff
cosplay-yesterday.line: I even caught my friend Sparrow staring at my legs, and he's as straight as it gets.

cosplay-yesterday.speaker: artemis
cosplay-yesterday.line: Ask if that's a good thing

cosplay-yesterday.speaker: zeff
cosplay-yesterday.line: Talk about how you ran away before Sparrow could notice you

cosplay-goodTime.speaker: artemis
cosplay-goodTime.line: Sounds like you had a good time.

cosplay-goodTime.speaker: zeff
cosplay-goodTime.line: Talk about how you ran away before Sparrow could notice you

cosplay-sparrow.speaker: artemis
cosplay-sparrow.line: Is that a good thing? Do you like Sparrow in that way?

cosplay-sparrow.speaker: zeff
cosplay-sparrow.line: Hah. No. He's really not my type, and even if he were, he's very very monogamously married. But it was still kind of flattering, I gotta say.

cosplay-sparrow.speaker: zeff
cosplay-sparrow.line: Talk about how you ran away before Sparrow could notice you

cosplay-ranAway.speaker: zeff
cosplay-ranAway.line: Of course, once I saw Sparrow, I had to get out of there before he could come up and get a closer look and realise it was me.

cosplay-ranAway.speaker: zeff
cosplay-ranAway.line: So, I booked it straight to my hotel room, washed off all my makeup, and changed back into my regular clothes before anyone could figure it out.

pronouns.speaker: artemis
pronouns.line: So... does this mean you identify as female? Should I use different pronouns for you?

pronouns.speaker: zeff
pronouns.line: Say you don't know yet, but he/him is okay for now

pronouns-she.speaker: zeff
pronouns-she.line: Actually, I've been thinking about this, and I'd really like to know what it's like be called she and her.

pronouns-she.speaker: zeff
pronouns-she.line: No one's ever used feminine pronouns for me before, for obvious reasons. But I've always wondered if they might fit me better.

pronouns-she.speaker: zeff
pronouns-she.line: And to tell you the truth, I don't think I completely identify as a woman, but I still like the sound of she and her.

pronouns-she.speaker: artemis
pronouns-she.line: Okay, then. She and her it is!

pronouns-ze.speaker: zeff
pronouns-ze.line: Actually, I've been thinking about this, and I'd really like to start using ze and zir for myself.

pronouns-ze.speaker: artemis
pronouns-ze.line: Say you haven't heard those pronouns before

pronouns-ze.speaker: artemis
pronouns-ze.line: Try to use the pronouns in a sentence

pronouns-haventHeard.speaker: artemis
pronouns-haventHeard.line: Ze and zir? I haven't heard those before. How do they work?

pronouns-haventHeard.speaker: zeff
